As the largest fast-growing developing country, China has seen an increase in its average family housing wealth from around 2,100 ==== in 1995 to around 100,000 ==== in 2017 (Li and Fan, 2020). However, the effects of rising wealth on health and health-related outcomes in China remains under-studied.====This paper considers the health-wealth nexus for the elderly in China and finds mixed evidence of wealth effects on health outcomes, with mostly negative impacts on healthy behaviours and healthcare utilisation among older adults. The seminal work of Grossman (1972) models the positive impact of wealth shocks on health status through increases in health-related investment. In contrast, another branch of the literature finds that positive income shocks may negatively affect health status via less healthy lifestyle choices (van Kippersluis, Galama, 2014, Apouey, Clark, 2015). Such conclusions are echoed in this paper: I observe older adults have less healthy lifestyles when experiencing positive wealth growth.====Previous literature suggests possible endogeneities, generally caused by reverse causalities and unobservable characteristics at the individual or household level, between one’s wealth and health status. I employ the simulated price method devised by Lovenheim and Mumford (2013) to identify the causal effects of wealth on health-related outcomes. The housing value serves as a proxy for household wealth in their method. This is reasonable because housing wealth accounts for more than 60% of household wealth in China (Li et al., 2020). The simulated price method employs a variation in house value in different households over waves caused only by prefecture city-level price changes.==== The exogeneity of this method is based on the assumption that the timing and magnitude of the housing boom in prefecture-level cities are not correlated with one’s health-related outcomes. The dataset used is the China Health and Retirement Longitudinal Study (CHARLS), which details health and health-related outcomes for people aged 45 and older, as well as prefecture-level information. I limit the regression sample to urban homeowners, given that the commercial housing market in China exists only in urban areas.====Applying the Lovenheim and Mumford (2013) method, I find that a 1,000,000-==== increase (equivalent to ==== $130,000 ====) in the total value of properties owned decreases the probability of having hypertension by 3.33 percentage points for the elderly in China. The same amount of growth increases the probability of having dyslipidemia and feeling depressed by 1.96 and 2.66 percentage points, respectively. In terms of healthy lifestyles, a positive wealth growth of 1,000,000 ==== reduces the probability of drinking/smoking and socialising with others by 2.48 and 1.37 percentage points, respectively. There is a negative effect of the same amount of growth on in-patient expenditures, the magnitude of which is 319.5 ==== (around $40).====There are two crucial subsample checks for the main results. One is for the difference in education levels, and the other is for the income disparity. The subsample results imply that the wealth increase imposes adverse effects on health status, especially on those with low education levels who are more likely to engage in unhealthy behaviours. The results also find income heterogeneity in response to wealth shocks, similar to the heterogeneity proposed by van Kippersluis and Galama (2014). To eliminate possible selection bias caused by residence relocations, I conduct a robustness check on the sample of those who had not moved since their first appearance in the survey. The findings from this limited sample are consistent with my primary conclusion. Other robustness checks, such as adding individual fixed effects and varying cluster levels, yield consistent results.====Previous studies have compiled evidence on the causal effects of wealth on health for developed countries, but primarily for middle-aged and younger individuals (Lindahl, 2005, Cesarini, Lindqvist, Östling, Wallace, 2016, Kim, Koh, 2021). In these works, lottery winnings and inheritance gains are used as exogenous shocks to household wealth. Using these exogenous shocks, Lindahl (2005) and Kim and Koh (2021) confirm the positive causal nexus; while Cesarini et al. (2016) find no evidence, which may result from the comprehensive social safety net in developed countries. Meanwhile, van Kippersluis and Galama (2014) show the harmful effects of wealth on health via unhealthy consumption. Hence, the directions of wealth effects remain debatable.====This paper is specifically related to the literature studying the effects of rising housing values on health-related outcomes. Most studies find positive effects of housing prices on health outcomes and healthcare expenditures in the U.S. and the EU (Davis, 2004, Fichera, Gathergood, 2016). More recently, papers have focused on the effects of the housing market on health in China, yet there is no consensus on whether the effects are positive or negative (Liu, Liu, 2020, Xu, Wang, 2020). Despite this attention, the health-wealth nexus for older adults has received little attention, especially in China. As China turns into an ageing society, the welfare of the elderly, particularly their health, has emerged as an important and understudied topic.====This paper seeks to fill this gap by documenting the health-wealth nexus for ageing people in China. One advantage of studying this nexus in China is that the country has insufficient public health insurance. The effects of wealth growth on health may be more significant than in developed countries with comprehensive social security systems. Surprisingly, this paper finds mostly negative wealth effects on healthcare use and healthy behaviours when controlling for health insurance status. One possible explanation for this negative wealth effect could be that health literacy in China is not as high as in developed countries (Yuan, Qian, Huang, Tian, Xiang, He, Feng, 2015, He, Cheng, Shao, Liu, Shao, Bishwajit, Feng, Feng, 2016). Sudden wealth increase without good health knowledge could worsen one’s health. The subsample results show that those with little education generally drive negative health outcomes with wealth increments, since poor health knowledge is often a concomitant of poor education. The results can be linked to the education component in health accumulation proposed in Grossman (1972), which states that education increases individuals’ efficiency in accumulating health capital. From this point of view, the results of this paper help reconcile the Grossman model and the literature on risky health behaviour.====The paper proceeds as follows. Section 2 provides a detailed background on the health-wealth nexus and the booming housing market in China. In Section 3, after a sketch of the theoretical framework underlying the health-wealth nexus, I introduce the empirical method and the results using the main identification method. Next come robustness checks and subsample analysis in Section 4. Section 5 concludes.
Title: The health-wealth nexus for the elderly: Evidence from the booming housing market in China

name: Hancock Stacey A.,Hill Andrew J.
institution: Department of Mathematical Sciences, Montana State University, USA,Department of Agricultural Economics & Economics, Montana State University, USA
publish_date: Received 31 August 2021, Revised 20 July 2022, Accepted 19 August 2022, Available online 20 August 2022, Version of Record 27 August 2022.
abstract: Many goods and services are produced in teams. We explore how teammate personality traits impact productivity on joint team tasks. Studying student teams at a large university and considering the “Big Five” personality characteristics of extroversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, emotional stability, and openness, we find that teammate conscientiousness has a small, positive impact on team performance: a one standard deviation increase in teammate conscientiousness increases performance on a team task by about three percent of a standard deviation in our preferred specification. The effect is evident holding teammate ability and gender fixed, and suggestively operates through improved team functioning and sustained increases in student effort. We also find evidence of positive spillovers from teammate openness and negative spillovers from teammate extroversion.
introduction: The extent to which personality traits can predict and explain behavior has been debated for decades. Increasing evidence indicates that they causally impact schooling and labor market outcomes (Borghans et al., 2008; Almlund et al., 2011; Borghans et al., 2016). But, many goods and services are produced in teams, and we know less about whether personality factors exert externalities on those around them, their teammates. Given the established evidence that peer attributes such as ability and gender affect individual decision-making and outcomes====, the potential for people to be impacted by the personality traits of their peers at school or work is clear. This paper adds to our understanding of peer spillovers by investigating whether the productivity of small teams is affected by the personality characteristics of team members.====We study three-person student teams in a large statistics course in college. Students are observed in multiple teams through the semester. Team production is measured by performance on team tests that are jointly taken in class by team members that have experience working together. This environment is particularly well-suited for studying peer effects within teams for three reasons. First, students are randomly assigned into teams, so potential nonrandom selection into peer groups is not a concern, and we can identify causal peer composition effects. Second, the course is structured so that students work repeatedly with their teammates for a month in a flipped classroom environment before taking the tests, providing an opportunity to observe both cumulative and contemporaneous personality spillovers. And, third, the team test questions we use to measure team production are subsets of individual test questions that are taken by students a few days before the team tests, so we have highly comparable measures of individual and team output that allow us to isolate the “value-added” of working with teammates rather than as an individual.====We find that a one standard deviation increase in teammate conscientiousness boosts question scores on team tests by about three percent of a standard deviation. This effect is small, but is similar in magnitude to other recently-estimated peer personality effects (such as Golsteyn et al. 2019). More suggestively, we also find negative effects of teammate extroversion and positive effects of teammate openness. Our richest specification includes student fixed effects and controls for the performances of team members on the recently taken individual test, so our estimated effect can be interpreted as the impact of peer personality holding the ability of the team constant. The estimates are also robust to including teammate gender and a measure of teammate baseline statistics comprehension in the model.====Conscientious teammates may improve team performance through a variety of channels. Indirectly, conscientious students are likely to work harder and exert more effort when studying on their own, and therefore may bring more knowledge and understanding into the team environment; we consider this an indirect ability effect. Directly, conscientious peers may positively influence the study efforts of teammates through the example they set, as well as improve team functioning by bringing focus and discipline to the team. In addition, external inputs into team production by instructors or other peers may be affected by the conscientiousness of team members.====We cannot explore all potential mechanisms with the data we have available, but consider a subset of prominent candidates. We speak to indirect ability effects by controlling for the recent individual achievement of teammates, but focus our attention on probing the direct mechanisms. First, we test if conscientious students induce changes in their peers’ study behavior by investigating whether the positive impacts of exposure to conscientious peers persist when the student is reassigned to a new team; if individual effects are sustained, students are likely changing their own work habits. And, second, we explore whether conscientious teammates improve team functioning by assessing if effects are larger on more complex tasks requiring more team coordination. Our results provide moderate support for both channels: teammate conscientiousness positively affects ==== individual test achievement, suggesting peer personality affects study behavior, and the impacts of teammate conscientiousness are somewhat more evident on complex questions requiring the most group coordination, evidence of better teamwork.====In our study, we measure personality factors using the “Big Five” personality traits of extroversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, emotional stability, and openness. It is argued that this five-factor model can fully describe an individual's personality.==== Although similar ideas existed earlier, the “Big Five” model in its current form was motivated by Goldberg (1990) who categorized a near-exhaustive list of known personality traits into these five factors. Many similar analyses have followed. We summarize the model in colloquial terms in the below table adapted from Diener and Lucas (2020):====Our paper is most closely related to Golsteyn et al. (2019) who investigate peer personality effects on individual achievement in a business school. Studying teaching sections of up to 16 students, they find that peer persistence, which is likely highly correlated with peer conscientiousness, increases individual test performance by about 2% of a standard deviation, which is similar in magnitude to our estimated effect on team test performance. Our paper has important distinguishing features. We primarily consider team output rather than individual output, and our peer groups are teams of three that work together on joint tasks in class rather than larger teaching sections. This is an important distinction; the extent to which individuals are affected by teammates on a joint task has parallels with many employment settings, and contrasts with the “softer” influence of peers in larger groups on individual output explored by Golsteyn et al. (2019). However, the unified evidence of hard working peers exerting positive externalities on their peers emphasizes the importance of personality traits in social interactions. This conclusion is also supported by Shure (2017), who uses within-school across-cohort variation to show that peer conscientiousness is positively related to secondary school grades, and Bietenbeck (2020), who uses data from Project STAR to show that having motivated classmates improves contemporaneous reading achievement.====In a recent paper, Weidmann and Deming (2021) conduct a novel laboratory experiment to identify individual contributions to team production. “Team players”, individuals who consistently cause their team to outperform their team's predicted production based on individual skills, are found to be endowed with more social intelligence, but are no different in terms of IQ, personality, education, and gender, in comparison to other team members. Our study shares two important features with theirs – measuring team performance controlling for the task-specific skills of individual team members, and observing individuals in multiple teams – but a key difference across our settings is the extent of team interactions. In our paper, teams work together for a month rather than once in a laboratory; it is not surprising that we find that teammate personality matters for team performance given team members have interacted repeatedly and over an extended period.====Two factors separate our findings from a literature in psychology that explores correlational relationships between team personality composition and team performance. The randomization of individuals into teams in our setting allows us to identify causal effects of team composition rather than associations, and the availability of highly comparable measures of individual and team performance allows us to explore effects on team “value-added”, the production of the team controlling for the productive capacity of individual team members. Peeters et al. (2006), in a meta-analysis of this literature, find evidence of a positive association between team conscientiousness and team output, similar to the causal effect we identify, but they also report a positive relationship between team agreeableness and team performance, which we do not find. Bell (2007) also uses meta-analytic techniques to provide an overall assessment of the psychology literature exploring relationships between team composition and team performance. She also finds that team mean conscientiousness is positively associated with team performance, but only in field settings and not in laboratory settings. This important distinction helps explain the difference between our finding from the field and that of Weidmann and Deming discussed above from a laboratory experiment in which no personality factor was associated with being a “team player”.====There is an established literature investigating peer effects in educational settings. Several papers exploit random assignment to peer groups in college as is done in our paper. Much of this work considers the impacts of college roommates (Sacerdote, 2001; Zimmerman, 2003; Stinebrickner and Stinebrickner, 2006) and peers in military academies (Carrell et al., 2009; Lyle, 2009; Jones and Kofoed, 2020), while more recent studies consider college cohorts and classrooms (Booij et al., 2017; Feld and Zölitz, 2017; Hill, 2017; Brenoe and Zölitz, 2019). These papers provide evidence that peer ability, peer gender and peer race all affect individual behavior and decision-making in college; in other words, there are spillovers associated with fixed peer attributes in college.====A smaller set of papers in the peer effects literature speaks to the possibility of behavioral-type peer externalities that are more similar to the peer personality impacts studied in this paper. In the college environment, Eisenberg et al. (2014) find evidence of peer effects in binge drinking; Figlio (2007) uses a creative name-based approach to show that boys more likely to be disruptive in class exert negative externalities on their peers in high school; and, in an elementary school context, Carrell and Hoekstra (2010) show that students whose in-class behavior is poor due to their home environments negatively impact their classmates. To the extent that individual behavior is predicted by the “Big Five” personality characteristics we study, our paper adds to this evidence that in-class behavior affects peers.====Our paper also speaks to a large literature on the relationships between “Big Five” personality traits and individual academic achievement. The findings we report on the causal effects of ==== personality traits are similar to some of the associations between ==== personality characteristics and achievement reported in the psychology literature. For example, Noftle and Robins (2007) find that individual conscientiousness is a strong predictor of both high school and college GPA; they report unconditional correlations of 0.20–0.24 between measures of conscientiousness and high school GPA in some models, which are an order of magnitude larger than the causal effects we document for peer conscientiousness. Saying that, magnitudes can be difficult to compare across studies and environments, and the associations between own conscientiousness and test performance that we subsequently report in this paper in a directly comparable setting are similar in magnitude to our estimated effects of teammate conscientiousness. And a meta-analysis conducted by O'Connor and Paunonen (2007) not only finds this conscientiousness-achievement relationship, but also reports suggestive evidence that school performance is negatively correlated with extroversion and positively associated with openness; the latter relationships are in the same direction as the secondary effects we find for peer extroversion and peer openness. Taken as a whole, the personality traits associated with individual achievement appear to causally affect the performance of peers in similar ways.====In addition, evidence of personality spillovers is important for policy evaluation. Given the increasing empirical support that educational interventions improve socio-emotional skills (Dee and West, 2011; West et al., 2016), the potential for socio-emotional skills to be related to the personality factors we study, and that these impacts may ultimately be more persistent than the effects on test scores (Heckman et al., 2013), we underestimate the returns to policies if we do not incorporate positive externalities such as those found in our study into program evaluations.
Title: The effect of teammate personality on team production

name: Fallick Bruce,Villar Daniel,Wascher William
institution: Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, Cleveland, OH 44101, United States,Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, Washington, DC 20551, United States
publish_date: Received 12 April 2021, Revised 2 May 2022, Accepted 14 August 2022, Available online 17 August 2022, Version of Record 24 August 2022.
abstract: Rigidity in wages has long been thought to impede the functioning of labor markets. In this paper, we investigate how the degree of downward nominal wage rigidity in U.S. labor markets has changed over time using job-level data from a nationally representative establishment-based compensation survey collected by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. After defining two types of downward nominal rigidity (operative and potential) often used in macroeconomic models of business fluctuations, we employ three distinct methods to examine the magnitude of downward nominal rigidity in the U.S. labor market, whether each type of rigidity is more or less severe in the presence of negative economic shocks than in more normal economic times, and how the degree of rigidity changed as ==== trended downward. We find no evidence that the high degree of labor market distress during the Global Financial Crisis resulted in a change in the extent of potential downward rigidity in nominal wage changes, though we do observe a downward trend in potential rigidity as wage inflation fell over the broad stretch of our data. In contrast, we find that operative rigidity was both countercyclical and increased at lower rates of inflation. In addition, we find a much lower degree of both types of downward nominal rigidity at multi-year horizons.
introduction: Rigidity in wages has long been thought to affect the functioning of labor markets. Such rigidity can take different forms, with differing implications for unemployment and other aspects of economic performance. Rigidities could arise from explicit or implicit contracting, efficiency wages, fixed-length nominal wage agreements, menu costs in the wage-setting process, government regulations, or informational or behavioral factors.====One strand of the research on wage flexibility has focused on asymmetric rigidities in the nominal wage-setting process—most notably the downward nominal wage rigidity posited by Keynes (1936) and, later, Tobin (1972), who argued that downward nominal wage rigidity might lead to undesirable macroeconomic consequences at low levels of inflation and that to “grease the wheels of the labor market,” it would be optimal to target an inflation rate somewhat above zero.====With consumer price inflation often running well over 5 percent in the 1970s and early 1980s, such concerns were seen as mostly immaterial: The costs of inflation were viewed as clearly exceeding any potential benefits, and rarely would employers have had to resort to cutting nominal wage rates in order to reduce real wage rates. However, as inflation declined to 2 percent or less by the mid-1990s, the question of whether workers or firms resist nominal wage cuts—and the consequences for labor market performance—became increasingly relevant. Indeed, the possibility that nominal wages were downwardly rigid accorded with indications from a variety of surveys (Blinder and Choi, 1990; Bewley, 2002; Smith, 2015; Du Caju et al., 2015) that declines in real wages caused by price increases are more acceptable to workers than nominal wage cuts and that employers are often reluctant to cut nominal wages because, among other factors, they believe such cuts would damage worker morale.====Empirical research to assess the extent of downward nominal wage rigidity in actual wages initially focused on micro-level data from household surveys. For example, research by McLaughlin (1994), Lebow et al. (1995), and Kahn (1997) used individual-level wage changes constructed from the Panel Survey of Income Dynamics (PSID) to test for the presence of downward nominal rigidity and found limited supporting evidence, especially for hourly wage workers. However, concerns about the prevalence of measurement error in the wage changes constructed from these surveys (for example, Bound and Krueger, 1991; Gottschalk, 2005) led many to question the reliability of the findings from this research.====In response, other researchers turned to employer surveys, which are thought to suffer less from misreported wages (Wilson, 1999; Altonji and Devereux, 2000).==== These studies generally found a larger role for downward nominal wage rigidity. However, much of the research that has used firm-level data has been based on case studies or on samples of only a small number of firms, and thus seems of limited applicability to the U.S. economy as a whole. An exception is Lebow et al. (2003), who used the same nationally representative data set that we employ in this paper and found that downward nominal wage rigidity reduced the number of nominal wage cuts by about half over their sample period.====Some researchers have recently used administrative data from the unemployment insurance tax system or wage records from payroll processing firms to assess the presence of downward nominal wage rigidity.==== For example, Kurmann and McEntarfer (2019) and Jardim et al. (2019) used payroll tax records from Washington state, where the state unemployment insurance system requires employers to report both quarterly earnings and quarterly hours for each employee (thereby enabling the researchers to construct an hourly wage). Both sets of researchers found that roughly 20 percent of job stayers experienced nominal wage cuts over the sample period they study, while less than 10 percent had their earnings frozen.==== Meanwhile, Grigsby et al. (2021) used wage records from the payroll processing firm ADP and found that only 2 percent of workers experienced a reduction in their base wage in a given year, while 35 percent experienced no change in their base wage.====Despite the evidence for downward nominal wage rigidity in the United States, whether this rigidity has important macroeconomic consequences remains an open question. Many researchers find little evidence that this form of rigidity has had material consequences for the performance of the labor market, suggesting that employers can often find ways to adjust their labor costs without having to cut nominal wages. For example, Lebow et al. (2003) found only weak evidence of an effect of downward nominal wage rigidity on aggregate wages in a wage-price Phillips curve model, which they attributed partly to a tendency for employers to use benefits to offset the rigidity in nominal wages.==== Meanwhile, Elsby (2009) and Stüber and Beissinger (2012) provided evidence that firms respond to downward nominal wage rigidity by compressing the wage structure for other employees, effectively offsetting the effects of rigidity on aggregate wage growth. And, more recently, Kurmann and McEntarfer (2019) reported that the downward nominal wage rigidity apparent in nominal hourly wage rates is not evident in annual earnings, suggesting that employers respond to the downward rigidity in wages by reducing the hours worked by their employees.====Macroeconomic consequences may also depend on the extent to which downward nominal rigidity binds during periods of severe economic distress, such as the period during and after the Global Financial Crisis of 2008-09, when the unemployment rate reached 10 percent and price deflation was at times seen as a distinct possibility. On the one hand, employers who are disinclined to cut wages might implement company-wide wage freezes in a sharp economic downturn. On the other hand, the surveys conducted by Kahneman et al. (1986) and Bewley (1995) both suggested that employees find nominal wage cuts mostly unobjectionable if a firm is losing money.====However, the evidence on this from previous research is mixed. Using data from the Current Population Survey (CPS), Daly et al. (2012) and Daly and Hobijn (2014) found a noticeable rise between 2007 and 2011 in the percentage of workers in the same job who reported no change in their wage relative to a year earlier, with the proportion of workers with no change in 2011 higher than in any period since the beginning of their sample period in 1983==== suggesting that employers were reluctant to cut wages despite the adverse demand shocks associated with the financial crisis. Using the same data, Jo (2021) found that the spike at zero has been countercyclical since 1979. In contrast, Elsby et al. (2016), using data on workers who had been with the same employer for at least a year, found that the size of the spike at zero increased only modestly during and shortly after the Global Financial Crisis, and was accompanied by a more pronounced rise in nominal wage cuts, suggesting an increase in the degree of wage flexibility.====A related question is how the extent of downward nominal rigidity has responded to the downtrend in overall wage (and price) inflation since the early 1980s. Gordon (1996, p.62) and Mankiw (1996, p.69), for example, argued that nominal rigidity would be less prevalent in environments of low inflation because workers’ aversion to nominal wage cuts would be reduced in an environment of price stability in which nominal wage declines were more common.====In this paper, we add to the evidence on these two questions of how downward nominal wage rigidity has changed over time using establishment-level data from a nationally representative compensation survey collected by the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS). Using three distinct methods proposed in the literature to measure rigidity, we place a particular emphasis on how downward nominal rigidity varies over the business cycle and with overall wage inflation.====In addition, under some assumptions we can use our methods to assess both the extent to which actual wage changes were constrained by downward nominal wage rigidity (which we will refer to as “operative rigidity”); and whether there were behavioral changes on the part of employers and workers—notably, whether individual or employer norms toward nominal wage cuts respond to prolonged periods of low inflation or economic stress—that result in a change in the potential for downward nominal wage rigidity to bind (which we will refer to as “potential rigidity”). Put another way, we define potential rigidity as reflecting the frictions in the wage-setting system, while operative rigidity is the outcome of those frictions interacting with otherwise-desired wage changes. We then focus on the Global Financial Crisis and subsequent slow recovery to assess whether downward nominal wage rigidity is more or less common in the presence of severe negative economic shocks than in more normal economic times. We also examine how this rigidity evolved as inflation trended downward over our sample period.====As is the case with many earlier studies, we find a significant amount of downward nominal wage rigidity in the United States at a 12-month horizon, both in terms of the proportion of wage changes that were actually constrained by downward nominal wage rigidity and in the proportion potentially subject to such rigidity should the notional wage change fall below zero. Although one might have expected the costs of wage rigidity to be too burdensome to maintain in a sharp economic downturn, we find no evidence that the high degree of labor market distress during the Global Financial Crisis resulted in a change in the extent of potential downward rigidity in nominal wage changes. Additionally, one might expect firms to adapt to a generally lower level of inflation by more readily reducing nominal wage rates, and we do find a downward trend in our measures of potential rigidity as inflation fell over the broad stretch of our sample period. In contrast, we find that operative rigidity is both countercyclical and increases at lower rates of inflation. Finally, we also report evidence suggesting that a likely reason for the lack of macroeconomic consequences from downward nominal wage rigidity is that firms often take a multi-year view of labor costs when implementing their compensation practices.====The rest of the paper proceeds as follows. Section 2 describes the dataset we use to conduct our analysis, provides some summary statistics, and discusses the pros and cons of using a job-focused survey of wages. Section 3 presents some simple histograms of the nominal wage change distribution for selected years in our sample. Section 4 describes the various estimators we use to examine properties of the wage change distribution for signs of downward nominal wage rigidity. Section 5 presents the results. Section 6 concludes.
Title: Downward nominal wage rigidity in the United States in times of economic distress and low inflation

name: Albagli Elías,Contreras Gabriela,Tapia Matías,Wlasiuk Juan M.
institution: Central Bank of Chile, Chile
publish_date: Received 8 February 2021, Revised 12 April 2022, Accepted 11 August 2022, Available online 15 August 2022, Version of Record 29 August 2022.
abstract: This paper contributes to the literature on the effect of the unemployment rate on individual job earnings using administrative data for the universe of formal wage earners in Chile. A key advantage of the data is that it provides precise measures of the length of job transitions and the tenure of job keepers, which we show is important to understand the ==== of earnings. Consistent with the previous literature, we find that newly created jobs (new hires) earnings are significantly more sensitive to aggregate unemployment than those of continuing jobs (job keepers). However, and contrary to recent evidence for the US, the larger sensitivity of the earnings of new jobs is a feature of both job-to-job movements as well as hires within the first year of non-employment, transitions for which wage sensitivity is less likely to be driven by cyclicality in the quality of new jobs. We also find a relevant degree of heterogeneity in the cyclical response of earnings among job keepers, with earnings being less cyclical for workers with longer tenure. These results highlight that the precise length of tenure and job transitions is relevant to correctly understand the cyclicality of wages. Our results are robust to controlling for changes in the workers’ relative wage position, suggesting that earnings cyclicality is not only an artifact of the behavior of job transitions inside and outside the firm.
introduction: The cyclical behavior of real wages, which has direct implications for the dynamics of aggregate employment and output in response to shocks, has justifiably been a central topic in the macroeconomics and labor economics literature for decades. Typically, aggregate wage measures appeared to suggest that wages fluctuated little over the cycle or even that they moved countercyclically, a notion that seemed consistent with traditional Keynesian models with wage rigidities.====However, a large literature starting from Bils (1985) has shown, using data for the US and Europe, that individual-level information can provide valuable insights that are lost with aggregate wage indices.==== A central finding in this literature is that the behavior of aggregate wages not only reflects the evolution of individual wages but also changes in the skill composition of aggregate employment along the business cycle. These changes in the composition of the employment pool can dampen or even revert the aggregate effects of the changes in worker-level wages, leading to relevant differences between the inferences derived from wage indices and those that come from the actual wages of individuals. In particular, estimates of wage cyclicality using individual-level data are typically larger than those from aggregate indicators.====An important additional insight from this literature is that the wage cyclicality of new hires is substantially larger than that of workers that keep their job. This finding is consistent with the ideas in Pissarides (2009), who argues that the relevant measure of wage flexibility comes from the behavior of the present discounted value of wages of new hires rather than from overall wages. Under that interpretation, the wages of new hires are associated with the relevant marginal cost of labor for firms. Therefore, wage flexibility among new hires will facilitate labor adjustment along the cycle.====However, Gertler and Trigari (2009) and Hagedorn and Manovsk (2013) argue that existing empirical studies may be picking up the procyclical nature of the match quality of job-to-job transitions rather than the actual cyclicality of individual wages. In this line of argument, recent work by Gertler et al. (2020) uses higher frequency data for the US to separate new hires coming from job-to-job transitions from new hires that come out of the unemployment pool. They find that while the wage cyclicality of workers experiencing job-to-job transitions is quite large, the wage cyclicality of new hires coming out of non-employment is similar to that of keepers. Under their interpretation, it is not that wages themselves are procyclical but rather that their apparent cyclicality is driven by the cyclical pattern in the quality of job transitions. Therefore, real wages in new employment relationships tend to move up (down) when unemployment is low (high), not because wages for a given job increase (fall), but because direct transitions towards higher-quality jobs become more (less) frequent and job gains from transitions become larger (smaller). This affects the estimated response of wages among workers that move across jobs directly –which are more likely to represent voluntary movements up a job ladder towards better jobs– but does not change the response of workers who transition through unemployment –whose movements have no systematic relationship with quality improvements, as on average they are likely to return to a similar job.====This paper contributes to this literature by using tax records for a census of workers and firms in Chile between 2005 and 2016 to address in detail the heterogeneity of labor earnings cyclicality across different types of employment relationships (ERs). A relevant advantage of our data is that it allows us to identify the ERs at a monthly frequency. This provides a detailed characterization of the duration of continuing jobs and the length of job transitions associated with new hires, and expands the previous literature in a relevant dimension. While a significant number of papers have lumped all new hires as a unique category that compares to job keepers, we, as in Gertler et al. (2020) or Lydon and Lozej (2018), can separate direct job-to-job transitions from hires out of non-employment. However, we can provide a more precise characterization of hires from non-employment by identifying the precise duration of their transitions, arguing that the length of the non-employment spell is relevant for the behavior of earnings. Similarly, we can exploit the heterogeneity in tenure among job keepers. Detailed information on the within-firm earnings distribution allows us to build proxies that control for transitions across job positions, and to explore heterogeneity in the cyclicality of wages across workers and firms of different types. Importantly, our data has information on the worker’s complete labor earnings, including wages and other forms of labor compensation. We think that using total earnings provides a better measure of the relevant cost of labor and its adjustment across the business cycle.====We highlight three main results that are important for the recent debate on the relevant margins of wage adjustment throughout the business cycle.====First, and in line with previous literature, we find that the earnings of newly created jobs (new hires) are significantly more sensitive to aggregate unemployment than those of continuing jobs (job keepers). However, contrary to the recent evidence provided in Gertler et al. (2020) for the US, the larger sensitivity of new jobs earnings is a feature of both job-to-job transitions as well as hires from relatively short spells of non-employment of up to two quarters.====Second, we find a significant degree of heterogeneity within continuing jobs. While the earnings of long-tenure job keepers have the lowest degree of cyclicality, the earnings of short-tenure workers have a significant degree of cyclicality.====Third, we find that results are robust to changes in the worker’s relative earnings, suggesting that the cyclicality of earnings is not driven by job improvements or demotions (either within the firm or towards a new firm). Moreover, the overall qualitative patterns hold across worker and firm characteristics. We also find that the overall cyclicality of earnings is decreasing on the worker’s age and income, as well as on firm size, a result largely driven by composition, and that the earnings of male workers are significantly more procyclical than those of women regardless of employment status.====As a bottom line, our results support the notion that individual earnings in Chile are procyclical, with magnitudes that fall within the boundaries of estimates found for other countries, and that this result is not solely driven by the cyclicality of direct job transitions but also by job transitions with relatively short non-employment spells and by workers with short tenures. Moreover, while we confirm the relative stability of wages for continuing jobs, the richness of the data allows to uncover interesting heterogeneity patterns in wage cyclicality depending on job tenure. These findings suggest that workers earnings are flexible, allowing the labor market to accommodate aggregate shocks.====A final contribution of the paper is to expand the scope of the literature, typically focused on data for the US and Europe, with data from an emerging economy. Chile is an interesting case study on the cyclicality of labor compensation for several reasons. First, it is a small open economy with relevant exposure to relative price shocks. In that context, the flexibility of wages plays a key role in the labor market’s ability to adjust to a volatile environment. Second, Chile has a high level of average turnover by international standards, with large job creation/destruction rates at the firm level and short employment spells/large number of job transitions for individual workers (Albagli et al., 2017). This suggests the existence of a very active labor market with a large degree of mobility. Our estimates suggest that earnings cyclicality in Chile is in line with estimated cyclicality in countries as Portugal, but seems significantly larger than the values estimated for other countries like Germany.====The outline of the paper is as follows. Section 2 describes the data. Section 3 presents the empirical strategy and the baseline results for earnings cyclicality for different categories of existing jobs and new hires. Section 4 explores heterogeneity in the cyclical response of wages across firms and workers of different types. Section 5 concludes.
Title: Earnings cyclicality of new and continuing jobs: The role of tenure and transition length

abstract: This study investigates the effect of intrahousehold property ownership on family structure using a difference-in-differences (DID) strategy and an exogenous source of variation in housing property ownership in China. Specifically, a 2011 revision of the marriage law changed the property division rule upon divorce from an equal division to a title-based division under certain circumstances, leading to a loss in intrahousehold property ownership for some women. The main results show that the loss of housing property ownership deteriorates wives’ outside option, lowers the probability of divorce and increases the likelihood that they will remain in a low quality marriage. Further effects include an inducement for the husband’s parents to move in, who bring more traditional gender norms to the core family, become involved in household decision-making and thus influence the young couple’s behaviors. Consequently, women are less likely to work in the labor market and shoulder a greater share of chores between themselves and their husbands. introduction: Economists have long been interested in intrahousehold decision-making and resource allocation, and the theoretical frameworks have progressed from unitary to bargaining models. In a standard bargaining model, two spouses with different preferences bargain over resource allocation and other family decisions. In particular, each spouse faces a threat point which is the utility he/she would gain in the case of divorce. As each spouse’s potential opportunities and endowments outside the marriage can shift the threat point, this can cause the intrahousehold bargaining power to change. Consequently, family decisions and well-being within the marriage are affected by each spouse’s predictions of their status outside the marriage.====An extensive literature has been established to examine the bargaining process, and intrahousehold bargaining power has been found to affect a household’s total assets, consumption of male-/female-preferred goods, family violence, women’s physical and mental health, labor supply, time spent on chores, subjective well-being, and children’s health and educational outcomes (e.g. Adam, Hoddinott, Ligon, Brown, 2009, Doss, 2006, Doss, 2013, Heath, Tan, 2020, Qian, 2008, Stevenson, Wolfers, 2006, Voena, 2015).==== Previous studies have developed various proxies of intrahousehold bargaining power, and women’s individual ownership of property (including land, housing property, dowry and a broader range of other assets) has been shown to be important, as it is a direct indicator of the wife’s outside option.====This study investigates the effect of an exogenous change in the intrahousehold housing property division rule in China in 2011 on intrahousehold bargaining power through a shift in outside options. Previously, the rule for dividing housing property upon divorce was either an equal division or it was ambiguous. The reform in 2011 established a new division rule whereby property rights are protected by the registered names and contributions at time of purchase. As this exogenous change in the law affects couples whose home is registered under one spouse’s name the most, while those who are jointly registered are not likely to be affected, it thus provides an opportunity to apply a difference-in-differences strategy to estimate the causal effect of a change in individual intrahousehold property ownership. This study focuses on the outcomes under several aspects of family structure including divorce, fertility and co-residence with the husband’s parents and also examines the effects on women’s labor market supply.====As divorce typically defines the threat point in the bargaining model, this study is related to the literature examining the effect of divorce law reforms on household divorce decisions. Numerous studies, including Gonzlez and Viitanen (2009); Mechoulan (2006); Wolfers (2006), have estimated the effect of a change in the divorce regime from consent divorce to no-fault unilateral divorce in the United States and Europe, and they generally find that the regime change reduced the cost of divorce and increased the divorce rate. This study contributes to the literature by examining the effect on bargaining status due to a divorce law change that creates unequal shocks, as the change in the cost of divorce is different for the two spouses. Moreover, this study examines the divorce decision from the more fine-grained perspective of individual-level marital dynamics instead of the aggregate state-level divorce rate that is widely used in the literature. The use of micro data is beneficial in the context since it allows us to relate divorce results to other family and individual behaviors that are difficult to observe in aggregate data, and to conduct heterogeneity analysis, so that we could not only examine the divorce level change, but achieve a broader understanding of how and on whom the divorce law reform takes effects as well.====This study is also related to the emerging literature studying the causal relation between intrahousehold bargaining and other aspects of family formation such as fertility decisions and intergenerational effects. Although the fertility decision is one of the most important outcomes of bargaining within a household, as men and women may show different preferences over the number and gender of children, the research is limited in spite of the rich literature on child development. Among the few existing studies, Harari (2019) finds that an improvement in women’s inheritance rights leads them to postpone marriage and childbirth. The existing literature also seldom relates women’s bargaining power to intergenerational interactions within the marital household. One exception is Mookerjee (2019), who finds that an improvement in women’s inheritance rights in India have empowered their participation in decision-making at the expense of the older generation and reduced the probability of living with parents-in-law. Examining these aspects of family structure are useful because they are among the most important real-world decisions to be made within a family, and these decisions provide insight into individual preferences and the intrahousehold bargaining process. In addition, as these decisions are also closely related to the well-being of women as well as other family members, their analysis can inform the evaluation of family-friendly policies.====This study also investigates the impact of intrahousehold bargaining on women’s labor supply which is typically considered as an individual decision in labor supply models but is often jointly determined together with family members in reality. Despite an extensive literature, the effects of bargaining power on female labor supply are mixed, and tend to vary according to cultural context. In the US, Chiappori et al. (2002) finds that divorce laws deemed favorable to women (regarding unilateral/mutual consent divorce, community property/common law, etc.) lead to a decrease in female labor supply and an increase in male labor supply in terms of hours worked through the standard income effect. In contrast, however, some studies of India (Field, Pande, Rigol, Schaner, Moore, 2021, Heath, Tan, 2020) find the opposite effect, with a strengthening of women’s bargaining power through inheritance regulation or financial training inducing women to enter the labor market, especially into high-paying jobs. They interpret this to be the result of traditional gender norms that inhibit women from working outside, and their willingness to participate in the labor market to gain more income once they are autonomous. Meanwhile, studies of Chile (Claudia Martnez, 2013) and Mexico (Hoehn-Velasco and Penglase, 2021) find a limited labor supply response to divorce legislation. Though the literature is ambiguous, it has emphasized the importance of culture as an important factor in the relationship between intrahousehold bargaining power and labor market behaviors.====In view of cultural and social context, China has unique attributes, with social mores deeply rooted in Confucian ethics emphasizing patriarchy, respect for parents, and family harmony while the divorce rate has been surging in recent years. Despite this apparent incongruity, there are few studies on the relation between individual property rights and family outcomes in China and those that do tend to focus on the well-being of either men or women as individuals or the behaviors of the unmarried. The present study is most similar to Zang (2020), who finds that women’s loss of property ownership due to the same marriage law reform studied here harms married women in terms of their satisfaction with life, confidence in the future, and the amount of time doing housework or market work. Although that study focuses mainly on women’s subjective well-being, Sun and Zhang (2020) find that the same law has alleviated assortativeness on the original family background among the unmarried. Further, Wang (2014), examining the effect of changes in individual property rights due to a privatization of state-owned housing in China in 1994, finds that an individual-level transfer of property rights strengthens intrahousehold bargaining power towards male-favored goods consumption and time spent on chores among both men and women.====The main findings of the current study are as follows. First, women’s loss of intrahousehold property rights leads to a sizable decline in the probability of divorce one year later and a moderate but still important decline even in the long run (a decline of 1.6% compared to the control mean of 3.1% seven years after the policy change). This implies a lower marriage quality among the treatment group, and this is supported by the findings on fertility choice, for those affected by the reform were less likely to have children immediately after the policy came into force, though a catch-up effect is observed in the longer term. Second, there is a non-negligible and long-lasting increase in the probability of co-residence with the husband’s parents among treated women (an increase of 6.8% over the control mean of 29.4% seven years after the policy change). While the husband’s parents typically move in to help shoulder the household duties, they also bring traditional gender norms to the nuclear family and thus potentially change the young couple’s behaviors or even participate in the decision-making process. Third, possibly due to the stronger exposure to traditional gender roles, a negative policy effect is found on women’s labor market work status, though there is little effect observed on women’s hours of labor supply. Heterogeneity analysis results suggest that young women and women living in a house of high value are affected by the division rule change more.====These results indicate that the marriage law reform has hurt marriage quality on average, and the deterioration in women’s bargaining power led by the policy change is stable and persistent. Since the reform has caused a loss in treated women’s intrahousehold property ownership without changing the total amount of household property, this study provides further evidence that the unitary model does not adequately capture household decision-making. Furthermore, it emphasizes the importance of taking family structure into consideration in understanding the intrahousehold bargaining process.====One potential threat to the identification is that the control group can be affected by the reform, and thus the DID estimate will be biased. It is possible since 15%-20% of the control group households are observed to change the house registration to be under only the husbands’ names after the reform, so women in those households would also experience a property loss. Control group households can also be affected through indirect channels, such as siblings’ spillover effect, the change in the remarriage benefit, and the labor market equilibrium adjustment. To address this concern, we provide a detailed discussion of each channel, show that most channels are likely to lead to an underestimation of the treatment effect, and conduct a series of quantitative bound analyses to prove the size of the underestimate is reasonably small.====The contribution of this study is four-fold. First, it emphasizes family structure outcomes, starting from the direct impact of the change in property ownership on divorce, then extending the analysis to other aspects of family structure, and drawing implications on the bargaining process by investigating potential mechanisms. Particular attention is given to the change in intergenerational interactions and its impact on other household decisions, which are important in the Confucian context, yet rarely discussed to date. Second, the study exploits variations from an exogenous change in legislation to avoid the difficulty in handling the endogeneity with more individual dependent bargaining power proxies such as the amounts of personal income and a woman’s dowry. Third, the study adopts an alternative method and dataset to validate the study, which is further supported by several additional tests to confirm the robustness of the main findings. Lastly, the study broadens the literature on intrahousehold bargaining by contributing evidence from China, which may also provide insight into other East Asian and Southeast Asian cultures.====This paper is organized as follows. Section 2 introduces the institutional background of regulatory reform of property division upon divorce in China and background on marriage and housing property in the country. Section 3 discusses the identification strategy and the main data source, while Section 4 presents the main empirical results. Section 5 discusses the heterogeneity analysis, other potential concerns and robustness checks, and Section 6 concludes the paper.
Title: Intrahousehold property ownership, women’s bargaining power, and family structure

abstract: Using panel data from 1985 to 2019, we provide the first comprehensive investigation of the relationship between trade union membership and job satisfaction in Germany. Finally, using different estimation models, we investigate whether the effects vary by gender, age, birth year, and employment status.
introduction: Job satisfaction is often viewed as an indicator of the utility associated with work. Combining this interpretation with the assumption that individuals become trade union members if the associated benefits exceed the resulting costs, we can expect trade union members to exhibit higher job satisfaction than individuals who choose not to become union members. Early empirical studies, such as by Freeman (1978) and Borjas (1979), do not observe the predicted positive correlation and have sparked an intense debate, generating a multitude of investigations. Most subsequent cross-sectional analyses report a negative relationship. If employing panel data or accounting for the endogeneity of union membership, relatively little evidence for a negative impact of union membership remains. However, the theoretical expectation of a positive correlation rarely finds empirical support.====The vast majority of studies, for example, considered in the meta-analysis by Laroche (2016) and the surveys by Artz and Heywood (2021), Hammer and Avgar (2005), and Goerke (2021), are based on data from the UK and the US. Given the specificity of their industrial relations system, we cannot easily generalise the findings. Meanwhile, the relationship between union membership and job satisfaction for other economies has not been well documented. Moreover, analyses that can truly identify causal effects are rare.====In this paper, we fill part of the research lacunae implicitly described above. As our first contribution, we comprehensively analyse the linkage between trade union membership and job satisfaction for Germany, using data from the German Socio-Economic Panel from 1985 to 2019. Germany is an interesting subject of research because trade unions play an important role. They have almost eight million members. Net union density is around 16% and has declined substantially over the last decades (OECD and AIAS, 2021). Moreover, the linkage between collective bargaining coverage and union membership is much weaker in Germany than in, for example, the US, indicating different incentives to become a trade union member. In addition, co-determination at the firm level via works councils plays a vital role. Therefore, we provide additional insights on the function of bargaining coverage and co-determination for the relationship between union membership and job satisfaction. As our second contribution, we present an innovative approach using a time-variant instrumental variable (IV) to account for the possible endogeneity of union membership. In particular, we rely on the concurrent strength of unions at the sectoral and regional level. Third, we conduct a comprehensive subgroup analysis and investigate whether the relationship between union membership and job satisfaction varies by gender, age, birth year, and employment status.====We document a negative correlation between trade union membership and job satisfaction in Germany in Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) models. We do not discern a statistically significant relationship in Fixed Effects (FE) specifications, unless we separate between individuals who join the trade union and those who leave it. Adding information on collective bargaining coverage or co-determination at the workplace for a subset of years clarifies that the above-mentioned correlations are not determined by such labour market institutions. Specifications based on time-variant exogenous variations in a trade union membership suggest the absence of any causal effect of union membership on job satisfaction. Although we cannot directly prove the exogeneity assumption and there might be concerns about the violation of the exclusion restriction, we corroborate our key finding in various robustness checks. For instance, instead of using the contemporaneous IV, we apply the lagged IV, which may be more exogenous. We also aggregate the union density at different levels, which allows us to consider the possible spillover effect of our IV. The application of the ==== strategy suggests that our main finding holds if the IV affects job satisfaction partly through other channels. Finally, we find stronger correlations in OLS models for female, older, and part-time employees. However, estimates from FE and IV models are mostly statistically insignificant. Therefore, subgroup analyses yield qualitatively similar results as for the whole sample.====The further paper proceeds as follows: Section 2 describes the institutional background, clarifies what effects of union membership on job satisfaction may be expected in Germany, and summarises the extant empirical evidence. In Section 3, we introduce the data and describe the empirical model. Section 4 presents the findings. Section 5 concludes the paper. The online appendix provides additional information and documents the results from a number of robustness checks, which we briefly report in the main text.
Title: Job satisfaction and trade union membership in Germany

name: Maclean Johanna Catherine,Webber Douglas
institution: Associate Professor, Schar School of Policy and Government, George Mason University, 3351 Fairfax Drive Van Metre Hall, Arlington, VA 22201. National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER), Research Affiliate, Institute for Labor Economics (IZA Email: jmaclea@gmu.edu.,Senior Economist, Federal Reserve Board of Govenors, Research Affiliate, Institute for Labor Economics (IZA), Constitution Ave NW &, 20th St NW, Washington, D.C. 20551, United States
publish_date: Received 15 June 2020, Revised 3 July 2022, Accepted 28 July 2022, Available online 31 July 2022, Version of Record 6 August 2022.
abstract: We examine the wage effects of ==== market regulations that compel private insurers to offer continuing coverage to beneficiaries in the United States. We model wages at various points across the career as a function of the mandated number of months of continuing coverage at labor market entrance. More generous mandated continuing coverage at labor market entrance causes an initial wage decline of 1% that reverses after five years in the labor market, leading to higher wages later in the career. In particular, wage increases are observable up to 30 years after labor market entrance. We provide suggestive evidence that increased job mobility early in the career is a mechanism for observed wage effects.
introduction: Labor market entrance is a critically important period for establishing wage profiles (Topel and Ward, 1992; von Wachter, 2010; Gardecki and Neumark, 1998). During this period, workers gain skills and transition to higher paying jobs and/or jobs that offer a better worker-firm-specific match, which sets their wage course for their career. Features of the labor market that stifle job mobility can persistently lower wages. For example, studies show that workers who enter the labor market during a period of reduced aggregate demand have persistently, but not permanently, lower wage and non-wage compensation (Schwandt and Von Wachter, 2019; Kahn, 2010; Oreopoulos et al., 2012; Kondo, 2015; Genda et al., 2010; Maclean, 2014; Altonji et al., 2016; Arellano-Bover, 2020).====This paper studies the effect of regulations that compel private insurers to include continuing coverage in insurance plans on wages at various points across the career in the United States. Within the U.S., insurance coverage is tightly linked with employment, and firms are the main source of coverage among non-elderly adults. Following the continuing coverage regulations, many firms that offer insurance must include continuing coverage in their benefit packages. Economic models of mandated benefits imply that if workers value the benefit, firms will reduce wages paid to offset benefit costs. The mandates we study allow separating workers and their dependents to maintain access to employer-sponsored health insurance (ESI) for up to 20 months after leaving a job. These mandates, passed by states in the 1970s and 1980s, reflect the first government regulation of continuing coverage in the U.S.====Continuing coverage is plausibly valuable to younger workers since this benefit facilitates job mobility, in turn promoting skill accumulation and improved worker-job matching and thus higher wages. Because younger workers are more likely to change jobs than older workers (Groot and Verberne, 1997),==== younger workers are potentially identifiable to firms. The ability to identify workers likely to value the benefit allows firms to pass costs to this group through lower wages (Lahey, 2012). With this background, we expect an initial negative relationship between mandated continuing coverage at labor market entrance and wages (as firms reduce wages to offset benefit costs), which will become positive after workers can benefit from increased job mobility and improved job matches in early career.====As discussed earlier in this section, several previous studies have examined and documented the importance of labor market shocks early in the career. For example, Arellano-Bover (2020) shows unemployment rates (which measure aggregate demand) faced at ages 18–25 (typical labor market entry ages) are more important for worker skill measures at ages 39–59 than unemployment rates measured at ages 26–30 and 31–35 (i.e., ages after typical labor market entrance). In our setting, the labor market entry conditions (we focus on continuing coverage mandates and not unemployment rates) and the subsequent evolution of those conditions (i.e., continuing coverage mandates) are arguably even more important because the change in the mandate is permanent (i.e., no states repeal their mandates) and persistently impact workers.====We draw a panel of workers from the National Longitudinal Survey of Youth 1979 (NLSY79) and estimate two-way fixed-effects regressions to study continuing coverage mandate effects on wages measured at various points across the career. The NLSY79 is ideal for our research as the dataset tracks workers from labor market entrance through mid-career and has information on wages, job changes, and cumulative number of jobs, and detailed worker demographics. The time period in which our sample entered the labor market, 1973 to 1991, coincides with the initial roll-out of U.S. states’ continuing coverage mandates. Twenty-six states implemented a continuing coverage mandate, and several states increased the generosity of existing mandates. This near-ideal timing of a cohort of workers entering the labor market and substantial legislative action by states offers a unique opportunity to study how the ability to increase job mobility early in the career impacts wages. Using the NLSY79 is also beneficial as we examine a time period before the large-scale movement toward firm self-insurance in the U.S. Self-insured firms in the U.S. are insulated from state-level insurance regulations through the 1974 Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA). During the period when members of our sample entered the labor market, just 8% of firms were self-insured (McDonnell et al., 1986).====We find an initial decline in wages for new labor market entrants attributable to mandated continuing coverage: an additional month of continuing coverage eligibility reduces wages by 1% in the first five years in the labor market. Wages increase with work experience for workers subject to these mandates at labor market entrance. After ten years in the labor market, wages are 1% higher with each additional month of mandated continuing coverage at labor market entrance, and this effect persists through mid-career before dissipating by 30 years.====We provide suggestive evidence that increased job mobility—proxied by the propensity to change jobs and cumulative number of jobs held—is a potential mechanism for the observed wage effects. The mobility finding mirrors reductions in job lock documented in previous work using samples of the working-age males and exploiting the same source of variation that we leverage (Gruber and Madrian, 1994). We are the first study to show that policies that promote job mobility during an important career development stage have lasting effects on wages.
Title: Government regulation and wages: Evidence from continuing coverage mandates

name: Girsberger Esther Mirjam,Koomen Miriam,Krapf Matthias
institution: University of Technology Sydney, Australia,Swiss National Bank, Switzerland,University of Basel, Switzerland,University of Lausanne, Switzerland
publish_date: Received 28 January 2022, Revised 25 July 2022, Accepted 26 July 2022, Available online 28 July 2022, Version of Record 3 August 2022.
abstract: We study how interpersonal, cognitive, and manual skills affect employment and wages in a search and matching model through their impact on productivity, complementarity, job destruction, and the cost of unemployment. Combining several data sets on workers who acquired skills in ==== and training (VET), we quantify each channel, allowing for unobserved heterogeneity in ability. All three skills increase productivity, yet they affect job destruction rates differentially. While manual skills are associated with lower job destruction, interpersonal and cognitive skills have the opposite effect. Focusing on low-ability workers, we then estimate the value of VET. Through VET, wages increase up to 10% and unemployment drops by over 50%. Low-ability workers thus have particularly large benefits from acquiring manual skills because they increase wages and shield from unemployment.
introduction: Substantial changes in the demand for interpersonal, cognitive, and manual skills observed over recent decades (Beaudry, Green, Sand, 2016, Deming, 2017, Lindenlaub, 2017, Roys, Taber, 2019) have had far-reaching consequences for workers’ labour market outcomes such as wages and employment patterns. While the effect of multidimensional skills on wages, wage growth and job mobility has been extensively studied (Guvenen, Kuruscu, Tanaka, Wiczer, 2020, Ingram, Neumann, 2006, Lise, Postel-Vinay, 2020, Roys, Taber, 2019, Sanders, Taber, 2012), far less is known about how different skills affect unemployment. Understanding the link between skills and unemployment as well as how it interacts with other labour market outcomes is key both for workers who decide which skills to acquire and for policy makers who design education curricula.====In this paper, we investigate how skills affect labour market outcomes through four channels: direct productivity effects (Beaudry, Green, Sand, 2016, Deming, 2017), complementarity in firms’ demand for different skills (Weinberger, 2014), differential risk of job destruction (Balsmeier, Woerter, 2019, Taber, Vejlin, 2020), and the cost of unemployment which can reflect different skill depreciation rates (Edin, Gustavsson, 2008, Nakajima, 2012). We distinguish between three different skill types - interpersonal, cognitive, and manual - and three different labour market outcomes - unemployment, wages, and labour market transitions.====We present a search and matching model to examine how, through these four channels, skills jointly shape workers’ welfare in equilibrium. We focus on workers who acquired their skills in vocational education and training (VET). Since the VET skill content is regulated through education curricula and standardised exams, we can directly measure workers’ acquired interpersonal, cognitive, and manual skills. In our set-up, workers differ in their unobserved ability and their acquired multidimensional skills. We then estimate the value of VET and the skills it confers for low-ability workers and discuss how this value arises.====We take our model to the data using the Swiss setting, where two thirds of a cohort enrol in VET. We have detailed information on labour market outcomes and skills of workers from 2004 to 2009. Our skills data comes from the Berufsinformationszentrum (BIZ), a career-counselling centre run by the Swiss government. The BIZ provides a detailed list of skills used in each of a total of 220 vocational occupations, grouping skills into three broad categories: interpersonal, cognitive, and manual. For labour market outcomes we use the SESAM survey which merges the Swiss Labour Force Survey, a representative panel, with administrative data on employment histories, unemployment benefits, and wages. We match the BIZ skills to the SESAM survey using the 5-digit occupational code of the learned occupation (i.e. the occupation in which a worker received his vocational education).====We take advantage of our rich data set to account for possible correlation between unobserved ability and occupational choice. First, we limit our analysis to workers who have obtained a VET degree as their highest education level. These workers tend to come from the intermediate and lower parts of the ability distribution, in contrast to workers who continue their education after completing VET. This restriction ensures that all workers in the sample differ primarily in their acquired skill bundles, while having limited heterogeneity in unobserved ability. Second, we control for the observed occupation-specific academic requirement index developed by Stalder (2011) which classifies occupations by high, intermediate, or low requirement. We show that this measure is a valid proxy for workers’ average academic ability level on the occupational level. It enables us to disentangle the effects of ==== by meeting academic requirements of the training occupation from the effects of ==== on labour market outcomes. Variation within and across occupation clusters allows us to identify the model parameters using the Simulated Method of Moments.====Our estimation and simulation results offer the following insights. First, we find that all three skills have positive effects on productivity and wages, although to a different extent. Manual skills have the largest effect on productivity (at 1.24 Swiss francs per hour for an additional manual skill), followed by interpersonal and cognitive skills (at 1.15 and 0.59 Swiss francs per hour and skill, respectively).==== We also estimate a substantial productivity premium in occupations with intermediate and high academic requirement levels (of 5.14 and 13.16 Swiss francs an hour, respectively). The selection role of the academic requirement helps explain the relative ranking of productivity effects of skills, which may appear surprising at first sight. Occupations with high interpersonal and cognitive skills tend to require a high academic level. Hence, large productivity (and wage) gains accrue from meeting the high academic level rather than from acquiring interpersonal and cognitive skills ====. Second, our simulation results reveal that skill-specific job destruction greatly affects workers’ welfare through its impact on transitions into unemployment. Skill-specific job destruction also has an impact on wages, albeit a small one. This result highlights the importance of analysing different labour market outcomes jointly and using a combined measure of workers’ welfare. Finally, we quantify the skill-specific cost of unemployment, which is largest for cognitive and interpersonal skills. This cost drives down reservation wages of workers with cognitive and interpersonal skills, which makes them exit unemployment slightly faster.====The model set-up also allows us to shed light on the value of VET and the skills it confers. In a further analysis we focus on low-ability workers with and without a VET degree. We estimate wage returns to VET of around 4% to 10%. Workers’ welfare, however, increases by 50% to 80% because of a second and far more important channel: VET benefits workers through higher job arrival and lower job destruction rates. By improving labour market transitions, VET thus decreases the unemployment rate faced by low-ability workers by one-half. In addition, VET leads to an increase in low-ability workers’ reservation wages. This suggests that their low unemployment rate does not come at the cost of accepting low-paying jobs. This second analysis further pinpoints how labour market outcomes other than wages reveal crucial information about workers’ welfare.====Our paper offers important insights into the multimensionality of skills. Our findings reveal that workers with low ability maximise their welfare when acquiring manual and - to a lesser extent - cognitive skills. Occupations which confer and use many manual skills pay higher wages and shield workers better from the risk of unemployment. Low-ability workers should thus select into manual-skill-intensive occupations. Workers with higher ability, however, should select into occupations which have a high academic requirement level and thus pay substantial wage premia.
