Only a small fraction of high-academic-requirement occupations use manual skills, while most of these occupations use cognitive and interpersonal skills. Workers with higher ability may therefore find acquiring cognitive and interpersonal skills more beneficial.====Our findings suggest that a general push towards acquiring more cognitive (or interpersonal) skills will not make all workers better off. Instead, our results speak to Roys and Taber (2019), who find that manual skills remain important for low-ability workers. When choosing which skills to acquire, workers should thus not simply focus on which skills afford highest wages, but take their own ability type into account. Similarly, policy makers who design education curricula should be well aware that firms exhibit strong heterogeneity in their demand for different types of skills and academic requirements. There remains scope for training in manual skills, in particular for workers with lower ability.====This paper ties into two strands of the literature. First, our paper relates to the growing body of research on the specificity of human capital and returns to heterogeneous skills. Recent contributions suggest that the number of years of education alone is not a sufficient measure of skill and propose alternative measures based on observed characteristics of jobs held by workers (Autor, Levy, Murnane, 2003, Gathmann, Schönberg, 2010, Geel, Mure, Backes-Gellner, 2011, Ingram, Neumann, 2006, Kambourov, Manovskii, 2009, Lazear, 2009, Lise, Postel-Vinay, 2020, Poletaev, Robinson, 2008, Rinawi, Backes-Gellner, 2021) or workers’ observed initial abilities (Guvenen, Kuruscu, Tanaka, Wiczer, 2020, Lindqvist, Vestman, 2011, Lise, Postel-Vinay, 2020). A general finding is that individuals move to occupations with similar skill requirements and wages are closely related to skills. Second, it contributes to our understanding of how vocational education affects labour market outcomes. Vocational education is associated with facilitating school-to-work transitions and low youth unemployment (Dolado, 2015, Eichhorst, Rodríguez-Planas, Schmidl, Zimmermann, 2015, Plug, Groot, 1998, Ryan, 2001, Zimmermann, Biavaschi, Eichhorst, Giulietti, Kendzia, Muravyev, Pieters, Rodríguez-Planas, Schmidl, et al., 2013). However, evidence on longer-term labour market outcomes of vocational education is more scarce and more mixed (Adda, Dustmann, Meghir, Robin, 2013, Balestra, Backes-Gellner, 2017, Dearden, McIntosh, Myck, Vignoles, 2002, Hanushek, Schwerdt, Woessmann, Zhang, 2017, Kautz, Heckman, Diris, Ter Weel, Borghans, 2014, Rinawi, Backes-Gellner, 2021).====Our paper differs from these studies in two important aspects. First, our empirical analysis of labour market outcomes uses a simple search and matching model, in which labour market outcomes are analysed as equilibrium outcomes of the demand and supply of multidimensional skills. This allows us to quantify through which channels skills impact labour market outcomes beyond wages and to provide novel evidence on how differences in unemployment rates across skills arise. Our simple model is inspired by the search and matching frameworks developed by Flinn and Mullins (2015) (FM) on workers with different schooling levels and the recent contribution by Lise and Postel-Vinay (2020) (LP) who study wage growth, skill accumulation and depreciation over the life-cycle of workers characterised by multidimensional skills. Our labour market model features almost the same transmission channels (productivity, unemployment cost and job destruction) as FM if the schooling level was replaced by our multidimensional skills vector. However, our focus and analyses are different from FM and more closely related to LP. Like LP, we focus on workers with interpersonal, cognitive, and manual skills. Our analysis also differs from LP in that we (i) abstract from life-cycle dynamics and (ii) investigate how multidimensional skills affect unemployment and labour market transitions. We include skill-specific costs of unemployment and differential job destruction as additional channels for skills to impact labour market outcomes. These additional two channels are key in explaining the large differences observed in unemployment rates and reservation wages across different occupation groups.====Second, we contribute to the study of labour market outcomes of VET workers.==== We distinguish different occupations according to their level of interpersonal, cognitive, and manual skills as well as their academic requirement. This refined analysis provides new insights into the channels through which interpersonal, cognitive and manual skills affect labour market outcomes and their individual impact. We highlight that not all occupations confer the same returns in terms of wages and, more importantly, employment prospectives.====The paper proceeds as follows. Section 2 explains the institutional setting in Switzerland and describes the data. Section 3 presents empirical evidence on selection into occupations and on labour market outcomes. Section 4 introduces a simple search and matching model with heterogeneous workers. Section 5 outlines our structural estimation procedure and discusses identification. Section 6 presents the structural estimation results. Section 7 uses the estimated model and simulations to shed light on how skills affect labour market outcomes and quantifies the value of VET for low-ability workers. Section 8 concludes.
Title: Interpersonal, cognitive, and manual skills: How do they shape employment and wages?

name: Lekfuangfu Warn N.
institution: Department of Economics, Universidad Carlos III de Madrid, Madrid, Spain
publish_date: Received 30 January 2022, Revised 20 July 2022, Accepted 20 July 2022, Available online 25 July 2022, Version of Record 30 July 2022.
abstract: The paper provides credible evidence for life expectancy as a key determinant of optimal decisions on children's human capital accumulation. The widespread use of landmines in Cambodia's civil conflict since the 1970s, followed by a large-scale international landmine clearance effort, allows for the examination of a causal relationship between life expectancy and ====. A twofold increase in landmine clearance efforts in affected areas during the 2004-2005 period led to a sharp decline in the intensity of landmine casualty. I use a triple difference model that exploits spatial and temporal variations in landmine accidents together with the male-biased nature of landmine accidents to estimate the causal impacts of prime-age mortality risk on human capital outcomes. The estimates show a sizeable, negative effect of landmine mortality on both school attainments and health investments. When the source of mortality risk is replaced by common road traffic accidents, any mortality effect on schooling outcomes disappears, suggesting that household optimal decisions may respond differently to different sources of risk.
introduction: Earlier theoretical literature predicts that an increase in life expectancy raises the optimal level of human capital accumulation (Becker 1962, Ben-Porath 1967). Lower mortality is thought to raise expected returns to the investment by increasing the expected total lifetime productive gains from the labour market, and also the horizon over which benefits from earlier investments in human capital could be enjoyed (e.g., Galor and Weil 1999, Soares 2005, De la Croix and Licandro 1999, Cervellati and Sunde 2005, Hazan 2012). To test the theory, many empirical studies estimate the relationship between mortality and education outcomes.==== Particularly, in a developing country context, several recent studies exploit regional variations of various health conditions and provide causal evidence for the effects of life expectancy and mortality risk on decisions related to human capital investments. They also demonstrate that the scale of adverse effects of mortality risk is crucially sensitive to the timing at which the risk is presented to the individuals (e.g., Fortson 2011, Jayachandran and Lleras-Muney 2009).====In this work, I shift away from a conventional focus on changes in medical-related mortality risk, namely, medical innovations, infectious diseases, or epidemiological transition. Instead, I examine the implications of mortality risk that is resulted from the usage of warfare weaponry and other similar materials capable of terminating lives.==== Mortality risk derived from warfare weaponry is distinct from that of general health-related risk in two main ways. First, it is a source of mortality risk that is capable of shortening one's lifespan directly and instantaneously. Second, a risk of dying from warfare weaponry carries with it a stark element of fright and fear as it usually happens in open space - making it more easily to be witnessed and recalled compared to other more subtle medical causes.====Therefore, landmine prevalence and its entailed accidents in Cambodia is a suitable setting for my empirical examination. Furthermore, the main victims of landmine casualties in the country are prime-age adults – accounting for 80 percent of total casualties (CMVIS 2012). Precisely, this is the type of mortality risk that does not affect the whole lifespan of an individual but more specifically at the ages where individuals are active in the labour market. Given this setting, the analysis can concentrate on the prime-age survival probability, which is known to be a key determinant of schooling decisions (Cervellati and Sunde 2013, De la Croix and Licandro 2013, Strulik and Vollmer 2013).====In detail, my main empirical approach uses a triple difference estimation (TD hereafter), which exploits three key variations of landmine-related mortality risk: spatial, temporal, and gender-related. The spatial difference in landmine prevalence and accidents across Cambodia is a consequence of the military strategies of the Khmer Rouge at the end of Cambodia's civil conflict in the 1980s, which left the western part of the country more heavily mined. The within-district temporal variation comes from the timing of international collaborations of landmine clearance operations around the years 2004 and 2005. The third source of variation comes from the male-biased nature of landmine casualties in Cambodia. According to the casualty statistics, adult males account for around 90 percent of total landmine casualties in the past 20 years (CMVIS 2012, Roberts 2011). Therefore, the change in the intensity of landmine mortality contributes directly to Cambodian males’ life expectancy whilst leaving that of the females predominantly unchanged. Such a gender disparity in mortality risk allows me to use the females as another key comparison group in the analysis and therefore account for potential unobservables that vary across time and location but are gender-neutral. In sum, my measure of landmine mortality risk is the district-level number of gender-specific landmine casualties per 1,000 prime-age adults in a given year.====My analysis uses individual-level data on school attainment from the Cambodian 1998 and 2008 censuses (IPUMS samples). In the first set of the analysis, I estimate the effect of mortality risk on primary school attainment by, in effect, comparing the outcomes of male versus female respondents living in the same district in the 1998 and 2008 censuses. I find that an additional casualty per 1,000 prime-age population (landmine casualty rate or ==== hereafter) is associated with a 4.2 percentage points (====) decrease in the probability of having attended or graduated from primary school. This estimate is robust to reasonable changes in specification and estimation methods. In the second analysis, I look at the effect of mortality risk on secondary school attainment of another set of individuals from the censuses. The estimated marginal effect is higher – at 6.1 pp. Nonetheless, the effect on secondary school attainment declines to 3.1 pp when I alternatively use gender-specific LMR in the estimation.====In a supplementary analysis, I investigate the potential role of heuristic probability in determining the extent to which mortality risks affect human capital investment decisions. Judging the frequency of an event is found to be influenced by individuals’ subjective ability to remember or recall such events and therefore leads to an exaggeration of the risk magnitude in a situation where substantial publicity of the event or emotions are at play (Kahneman and Tversky 1979, Slovic et al. 1982). In this context, optimal decisions may not respond to a change in mortality risk from a low-probability event (landmine accidents) in the same way as that of a high-probability one (road traffic accidents) – even when both events are otherwise comparable (non-health, prime-age and male-biased mortality). The estimation shows that schooling outcomes of children are responsive to the mortality risk resulting from landmines, but not from road traffic accidents.====This article is also related to a growing literature that looks into the legacy of civil conflicts and violence on human capital development.==== The existing evidence points that the effects of violence on educational achievements are mostly heterogeneous - depending particularly on types of violence and educational outcomes. Recent studies have estimated the negative effects of being exposed to ongoing violence on educational performances Looking at the effect of drug-induced violence in Mexico, Brown and Velasquez (2017) suggest that financial hardship is a key driver of the negative effect on education outcomes, while Brück et al. (2019) focus on the implication of civil conflict on the West Bank on high school students. Brück et al. (2019) find that violent events reduce the supply-side of education.==== In contrast to Brown and Velasquez (2017) and Brück et al. (2019), I can separately isolate the role of changes in mortality risk on human capital accumulation in a situation whereby other relevant factors in the case of ongoing conflicts, for instance, uncertainties, school infrastructure damages, or psychological costs, are of fewer concerns (Koppensteiner and Menezes 2021, Gerardino 2014).====A smaller but growing literature has investigated the effect of landmines on socio-economic well-being. Closely related to my work is Merrouche (2011), which looks at the impact of exposure to landmine contamination during the civil conflict on the subsequent educational attainment of the affected birth cohorts. By focusing on the post-war period, my TD estimation can arguably shut off other confounding channels.==== In addition, a quasi-experimental study on landmine-driven amputees by Takasaki (2020) shed light on the effect of disability, poverty and adverse intergenerational consequence. In particular, he shows a decline in children's schooling and an increase in child labour in households with landmine-induced disabled parents.====The article proceeds as follows: the next section discusses the context surrounding landmines in Cambodia. Section 2 outlines the historical background of landmines and educational institutions in Cambodia. Section 3 describes the data. Section 4 presents the estimation strategy and main findings. Section 5 shows robustness checks. Section 6 explores possible mechanisms and Section 7 concludes. Supplementary results are presented in the Online Appendix.
Title: Mortality risk, perception, and human capital investments: The legacy of landmines in Cambodia

name: Cai Xiqian,Fan Qingliang,Yuan Congying
institution: Institute of Economics, School of Economics and Wang Yanan Institute for Studies in Economics, Xiamen University, Fujian, China,Department of Economics, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR,Wang Yanan Institute for Studies in Economics, Xiamen University, Fujian, China
publish_date: Received 14 December 2021, Revised 21 May 2022, Accepted 18 July 2022, Available online 23 July 2022, Version of Record 29 July 2022.
abstract: We utilize representative and randomly assigned class data in China to study how being integrated with classmates who are only children in a family affects students’ academic and non-cognitive outcomes. A single child has certain common characteristics related to
introduction: The only child family is now the fastest growing family unit in many countries.==== The rise of only children has resulted in a significant increase in the proportion of only child peers, which brings a great change to the classroom environment. This change may manifest in multiple ways. Since parents are more likely to notice and praise only children’s achievements, they might be more ambitious and have higher self-esteem, which would lead to a more competitive social interaction (Li and Qiu, 2021). On the other hand, only children do not learn social skills by interacting with siblings, which might affect their participation in some collective activities.====The role of social interactions in changing individual behaviors is central to many areas of social science. A bulk of recent economic literature have tried to document the effect of social interactions on economic and social outcomes in different real-world settings (Dahl, Løken, Mogstad, 2014, Hvide, Östberg, 2015, Nicoletti, et al., 2018, Opper, 2019). One question of particular interest is how social interactions in the classroom environment affect children’s development since the classroom is a key context for human capital accumulation. There is a general consensus that only children and non-only children exhibit differences in behaviors, such as cognitive functions and personality traits. These dramatic changes in the composition of only child peers might have a great influence on social interactions in the classroom environment, which may further affect students’ cognitive and non-cognitive abilities.====However, there is limited evidence regarding the causal role of only child peers’ composition on students’ cognitive and non-cognitive abilities. And there are at least two important reasons for understanding them. First of all, many believe that peer effects play an important role in determining students’ academic performance. Both policymakers and researchers have devoted a great deal of attention to consequences of peer effects in the classroom. Empirical studies have focused on a wide range of peer characteristics such as gender, ability, and social background (Ammermueller, Pischke, 2009, Angrist, Lang, 2004, Arcidiacono, Nicholson, 2005, Booij, Leuven, Oosterbeek, 2017, Carrell, Fullerton, West, 2009, Gong, Lu, Song, 2021, Sacerdote, 2001, Xu, Zhang, Zhou, 2020, Zimmerman, 2003). As the only child is becoming the norm, little is known about how only child peers influence the child’s development in the classroom. We have added to this literature by providing, to our knowledge for the first time, empirical evidence on the influence of only child peers on students’ cognitive and non-cognitive performance. Second, understanding the effects of only child composition in the classroom and the mechanisms that drive these effects could shed light on educational policies that improve students’ school performance, such as the optimal grouping of students into class, effective allocation of resources within schools, and designing educational programs to develop social and non-cognitive skills for all students. Our research also contributes to uncovering the mechanisms by utilizing unique data on both the behavior and beliefs of teachers and students. We directly tested how a teacher’s teaching behavior differs by only child composition in the classroom, as well as how parents’ educational investment, students’ behavior, and belief are influenced by the class’s only child composition.====The central problem of estimating peer influence in a school setting is the non-random grouping of students. Students may self-select into schools and classes based on their family background, personality traits, and innate abilities. Recently, some have addressed this selection issue through randomization (e.g., Chetty, Friedman, Hilger, Saez, Schanzenbach, Yagan, 2011, Duflo, Kremer, Robinson, 2011, Gong, Lu, Song, 2021, Sacerdote, 2001, Shue, 2013, Todd, Wolpin, 2018, Zimmerman, 2003). Others have employed cross-cohort variation (e.g., Black, Devereux, Salvanes, 2013, Carrell, Fullerton, West, 2009, Gould, Lavy, Daniele Paserman, 2009, Hoxby, 2000, Lavy, Schlosser, 2011). This study addresses the selection problem by utilizing a representative random assignment of students into the classroom in Chinese middle schools.====For this study, we employed a nationally representative middle school survey, 2013–2014 China Education Panel Survey (CEPS), to estimate how the composition of only child peers affects students’ cognitive and non-cognitive outcomes. To detect the causal effect, we restricted our sample to schools of student random assignment, and conducted balancing tests for students’ predetermined characteristics to confirm this randomized assignment. And school-grade fixed effects were also controlled for removing any school level factors.====We found that the composition of only children in the classroom has a significant positive effect on students’ academic performance. A 10% point rise in the composition of only child peers increases students’ test scores by 6.78% of a standard deviation. However, for non-cognitive outcomes, we found that students feel more mental stress when facing more only child classmates in the classroom. The impact of the composition of only child students on social development is also negative and statistically significant. Subjective well-being in school life seems to not have been changed by this group characteristic.====We then explore potential mechanisms driving the impact of only child peers on students’ cognitive and non-cognitive outcomes. We tested seven possible channels individually from four aspects of interactions in this education system: student-teacher interactions (praise and question, responsibility, discussion in lectures, teachers’ time allocation to lectures, grading and home visits), student-parent interactions, student-student interactions, and students’ learning efforts. We discovered that teachers will be more likely to be responsible if their class has a higher proportion of only children. This is possible because teachers have been influenced by the parents of only children, and paid more attention to their academic performance. However, teachers are more likely to tailor a less interactive teaching style in the lecture, and intra-student interactions are less friendly and satisfying. This phenomenon is associated with the composition of only child students, who are less cooperative and have social skills deficits (Cameron, Erkal, Gangadharan, Meng, 2013, Downey, Condron, Yucel, 2015, Merry, Bobbitt-Zeher, Downey, 2020); teaching practices and peer pressure are also strongly correlated with students’ beliefs about cooperation (Algan et al., 2013).====In the last part of our empirical analysis, to quantify the power of each mechanism explaining the effect of this group characteristic on students’ outcomes and their total explanatory power, we employed a mechanism decomposition method proposed by Heckman et al. (2013) and Gelbach (2016). The estimated decomposition of each mechanism documented that teachers’ praise and questions in a lecture, student-parent interactions, and student-student interactions explain a large share (32.524%) of the effect of the only child peer composition on academic performance. For social development, we found that the lack of student-student interactions explains approximately 22.503% of the loss of social development in school. For mental stress, teachers’ praise and questions, student-parent interactions and student-student interactions accounted for only 13.471%.====This paper is relevant to three dimensions of work in economics and education. The first dimension is the impact of an increasing number of children without siblings resulting from the low fertility intention and population control policy. A bulk of the literature focuses on this topic at the societal level, such as family structure changes, labor market shocks, and aging populations (Li, Zang, An, 2013, Maestas, Mullen, Powell, 2016, Razin, Sadka, Swagel, 2002, Zhang, 2017). From the view of resource allocation in economics, many researchers have also explored the quantity-quality tradeoff of children and resource dilution theory in the family setting (Becker, Lewis, 1973, Blake, 1981, Liu, 2014, Qin, Zhuang, Yang, 2017, Rosenzweig, Zhang, 2009, Stormshak, Bellanti, Bierman, 1996, Wang, Zhang, 2018, Wei, Wu, Lv, Zhou, Han, Liu, Luo, 2016). Recently, several researchers have gradually paid attention to the prosociality of only children during interactions with others; for example, social preferences. They found that only children are less trusting and less cooperative (Cameron, Erkal, Gangadharan, Meng, 2013, Li, Qiu, 2021) and fail to gain more social skills than their counterparts with siblings (Downey, Condron, 2004, Downey, Condron, Yucel, 2015, Whiteman, McHale, Soli, 2011). In the school setting, the prosociality of the only child cohort might alter the classroom environment, which might have a spillover effect on students’ outcomes. However, surprisingly, few papers have considered these potential problems. Our work will contribute to gaining insight into this point.====A second connection is thus in line with the empirical literature on the importance of social interactions on student outcomes. Manski (1993) divided social interactions into two parts: endogenous social interaction effects (group behaviors or ability) and exogenous social interaction effects (the contextual effect or group characteristics). Many works support the idea that endogenous social interaction effects play an important role in determining students’ performance (Duflo, Kremer, Robinson, 2011, Imberman, Kugler, Sacerdote, 2012, Kremer, Levy, 2008, Lefgren, 2004, Zimmerman, 2003). For example, group behaviors have a negative impact on students’ conduct, such as alcohol drinking, smoking and dropping out of high school (Gaviria, Raphael, 2001, Kremer, Levy, 2008, Li, Zang, An, 2013, Powell, Tauras, Ross, 2005). Booij et al. (2017) revealed that high-ability peers have positive effects on students’ test scores. Further, Dahl et al. (2020) found that social interactions within family networks determine students’ major choices in secondary school. Moreover, many studies indicate that endogenous social interaction effects have a “snowball effect” on individual behaviors or outcomes (e.g., positive group behavior affects positive students’ behavior, and positive students’ behavior reversely leads to more positive group behavior) (Blume, Brock, Durlauf, Jayaraman, 2015, Bramoullé, Djebbari, Fortin, 2009, Sacerdote, 2001). Even though group characteristics could not have a social multiplier effect through the feedback loop as group ability and behaviors, it involves a form of social learning as group risk aversion according to Young (2009), the classroom environment as the group gender effect in Gong et al. (2021), or prosociality formation as the group socioeconomic status effect in Kosse et al. (2020). Therefore, group characteristics could be important for understanding the formation of non-cognitive outcomes for students. This is vital for economics and education policymakers, as some scholars have found that the impact of social interactions on student academic outcomes will fade out in later grades, but non-cognitive outcomes will persist in the long run (Chetty et al., 2011). However, research has long ignored this group effect. We will extend the literature to a new dimension of group characteristics, the only child cohort, and examine the influence of this group feature on both students’ academic performance and non-cognitive outcomes.====This paper also provides evidence for the impact of social interactions on the classroom environment. Scholars paid limited attention to the mechanisms through which social interactions affect student development. Classmates, like family members, are the source of aspirations, information, motivation, and direct interactions in learning, and interactions with them will change students’ learning beliefs. Moreover, classmates may affect the classroom process; for example, classmates could aid learning through questions and answers in the lecture, and contribute to the pace of instruction (Lazear, 2001). Research in the field of cooperative learning has revealed that students could report increased efficacy and mastery goal orientation when their classes are organized more cooperatively (Adu, Galloway, 2015, Nichols, Miller, 1994, Zakaria, Chin, Daud, 2010). Social interactions among students also affect reading engagement (Guthrie et al., 1995). Moreover, successful peer relationships play an important role in the development of cognitive outcomes and school life adjustment (Berndt, Keefe, 1995, Ryan, Patrick, 2001). In our context, since parents have higher education expectations for only children than children with siblings, the classroom environment may be more competitive when it contains a larger composition of only children. Only children with limited social skills are also more likely to create a less information-sharing environment. Therefore, the behaviors of teachers, parents, and students who interact in the education system react to this change in the classroom environment, and will help us to further understand the deep mechanisms behind this story. In this paper, nationally representative questionnaires administered in China surveyed sufficient information covering student-teacher interactions, student-parent interactions, student-student interactions, and students’ learning efforts, which made the deep analysis possible. To decompose each mechanism, we used a novel method to estimate the relative weight of possible channels.====The rest of this paper proceeds as follows. In Section 2, we introduces this nationally representative education panel survey (CEPS) that we employed, as well as the descriptive statistics. Section 3 reviews the key challenge of estimating the effects of only child peers, and then describes the estimation strategy in our study. Section 4 presents and discusses empirical results on both cognitive and non-cognitive outcomes and robustness check results. Section 5 estimates the underlying mechanisms behind this story and the power of all possible channels. Section 6 discusses the heterogeneous influences of only child peers. Finally, Section 7 concludes our work and briefly reviews the implications of the findings.
Title: The impact of only child peers on students’ cognitive and non-cognitive outcomes

name: Gautier Erwan,Roux Sébastien,Suarez Castillo Milena
institution: Banque de France, France,Insee - Ined - CREST, France,Insee - CREST, France
publish_date: Received 16 December 2021, Revised 19 July 2022, Accepted 20 July 2022, Available online 22 July 2022, Version of Record 1 August 2022.
abstract: We document new empirical findings on the effects of wage setting institutions on wage rigidity using quarterly micro wage data matched with sectoral minimum wages. We first estimate a micro empirical model of wage rigidity that takes into account minimum wage dynamics. We then use a simulation method to investigate the implications of lumpy micro wage adjustment for aggregate wages. Both national and sectoral minimum wages have a large effect on the timing and on the size of wage adjustments. Minimum wage setting institutions contribute to increasing the time it takes to fully absorb a shock to wages by one year, although the resulting wage changes are significantly higher. Minimum wages contribute to amplifying, by a factor of 1.7, the response of wages to past
introduction: In standard macro models, wage stickiness is one of the key ingredients that generate fluctuations in employment or real effects of monetary policy (Erceg, Henderson, Levin, 2000, Smets, Wouters, 2003). Micro empirical evidence on wage rigidity is thus highly relevant for macro models and a recent literature has documented new stylized facts on wage stickiness (Taylor, 2016 for a survey). However, this literature often disregards minimum wage and collective wage bargaining as potential sources of wage rigidity when, in most European countries, they potentially affect the great majority of workers. This paper aims to fill this gap and provides new empirical evidence on how minimum wages – set at national level or collectively bargained at sectoral level – can shape aggregate wage dynamics.====The French labour market is a relevant case study because it has similar wage-setting institutional features to many other European countries: dominance of sectoral wage agreements, broad coverage of agreements because of extension procedures and the existence of a National Minimum Wage (NMW). Even if each European country is characterized by a specific combination of these features, we believe that more general lessons for the euro area can be drawn from the French results.====One key empirical challenge when measuring the impact of minimum wages on wage rigidity is to link - at the micro level and at an infra annual frequency - wage trajectories to the appropriate sector- and job-specific minimum wage. In this paper, we use a large dataset of individual wages collected at a quarterly frequency by the French Ministry of Labour over the period 2005 to 2015. We match this data set with quarterly hand-collected data on bargained sectoral wage floors for more than 350 industries (covering almost all workers in the private sector) and also with data on firm-level wage agreements.====Using this matched micro dataset on wages and minimum wages, we first estimate a microeconometric wage rigidity model in which the timing and the size of wage adjustments depend on inflation or unemployment but also on national or sectoral minimum wages. We then show that the aggregate wage response to a shock cannot easily be derived from parameter estimates of the micro wage rigidity model for two reasons. First, in this set-up, since wages are rigid at the micro level, a shock has long-lasting effects on aggregate wage dynamics and micro estimates do not provide any direct information about the speed of adjustment to a shock. Second, the transmission of a shock to wages is complicated by the existence of job-specific minimum wages. A shock can first affect negotiated minimum wages which then affect individual wages, leading to potential indirect effects of the initial shock on workers’ wages. One contribution of this paper is that using parameter estimates of our micro wage rigidity models, we simulate individual trajectories of wages and minimum wages, and we then aggregate these trajectories to describe how aggregate wages respond to a shock. Our simulation exercise allows us: (i) to assess aggregate wage persistence due to micro lumpiness in wage changes; and (ii) to investigate how minimum wages shape the transmission of a shock to aggregate wages.====We document three sets of new empirical findings. First, micro wage stickiness translates into a delayed aggregate wage response to a shock: a ==== increase in inflation takes a little under four years to be fully incorporated into wages. Taking state-dependent factors into account modifies the response of aggregate wage dynamics to a shock compared with a set-up where we assume exogenous frequency of wage adjustment. Second, we estimate the medium-run direct effects of the main drivers of aggregate wages. After five years, a ==== increase in inflation has a direct effect of 0.24 pp on aggregate wage increases, while unemployment has only a small negative effect. Another contribution of our paper is that we estimate the direct effects of minimum wages on aggregate wage dynamics. We find that after five years, a ==== increase in the NMW or sectoral wage floors has an impact of 0.13 pp and 0.16 pp respectively. Third, minimum wages amplify the effect of past inflation on aggregate wages. Once we allow the NMW and sectoral minimum wages to react to aggregate shocks, the overall effect of inflation on aggregate wages rises to 0.42 pp and the effect of the NMW to 0.17 pp.====Our paper is a contribution to the empirical literature documenting patterns of nominal wage rigidity. The first papers calibrating wage rigidity used firm-level wage agreement data for the United States and Canada (Cecchetti, 1987, Christofides, 1987, Christofides, Wilton, 1983, Taylor, 1983), or Sweden (Fregert and Jonung, 1998) and more recently for France (Avouyi-Dovi, Fougère, Gautier, 2013, Fougère, Gautier, Roux, 2018). On the other hand, a recent growing literature has documented new facts on wage rigidity using administrative sources of actual wage data (Barattieri, Basu, Gottschalk, 2014, Grigsby, Hurst, Yildirmaz, 2021) for the United States, (Le Bihan et al., 2012) for France, (Sigurdsson and Sigurdardottir, 2016) for Iceland or (Lunneman and Wintr, 2015) for Luxembourg. However, these papers do not include any information on minimum wages or collective wage agreements even though these minimum wages cover the vast majority of workers in European countries.==== Our contribution is to fill this gap and to do so, we build on two recent empirical papers using similar wage data for France: Fougère et al. (2018) focus on the dynamics of sectoral wage floors and their determinants, while Le Bihan et al. (2012) look at actual wage dynamics but without any information on negotiated wages. We combine both approaches by relating actual wages to sectoral wage floors, which allows us to document how negotiated wage adjustments shape the wage response to aggregate shocks.====The most recent wage rigidity literature usually investigates the main drivers of wage adjustments by estimating microeconometric models of wage rigidity.==== In this paper, we go one step further: we use simple simulation exercises to derive implications of micro wage rigidity for aggregate wage dynamics (in particular for the speed of aggregate wage adjustment). To our knowledge, this is the first attempt to derive empirically the implied aggregate wage dynamics from estimates of micro wage rigidity models. Moreover, using these simulation exercises, we are able to quantify quite precisely how national or sectoral minimum wages contribute to aggregate wage dynamics.====We also contribute to the empirical literature on the pass-through of minimum wages on other wages. Several empirical studies find that the NMW not only affects wages close to the NMW but has also spillover effects to higher wages (see for instance Autor, Manning, Smith, 2016, Card, Krueger, 1995, Fortin, Lemieux, Lloyd, 2021, Grossman, 1983, Neumark, Schweitzer, Wascher, 2004). Sectoral wage floors set by industry-level agreements can be a relevant channel through which the NMW can affect higher wages. In France - as in many European countries – each industry defines wage floors for representative occupations, and wage floors cannot be set below the NMW. Thus, when the NMW adjusts, industries have to update thousands of industry-level wage floors to keep them above the NMW. In addition, the NMW increase is regarded as the fair level for sectoral wage negotiations or as the norm and may be transmitted to the sectoral wage floors across the board.==== Wage floors then affect individual wages and are a possible channel of NMW spillover to higher wages (Dittrich et al., 2014). Our contribution is to quantify the empirical relevance of these spillover effects. We show that lower paid employees are more reliant on institutions (like the legal rule of NMW indexation) to achieve wage indexation whereas better paid workers are more able to protect their wage settlements (through collective wage bargaining) from the direct impact of inflation.====The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we present a simple sticky wage model in which wages depend on minimum wages and derive some implications for aggregate wage persistence. Section 3 presents our micro datasets and documents stylized facts relating wage and minimum wage nominal rigidities. In Section 4, we present the estimation results of our microeconometric model of wage rigidity. In Section 5, using a simulation-aggregation exercise, we document empirical results on how aggregate wages respond to shocks. Section 6 concludes.
Title: How do wage setting institutions affect wage rigidity? Evidence from French micro data

name: Zaresani Arezou,Olivo-Villabrille Miguel
institution: The University of Sydney, IZA and Tax and Transfer Policy Institute (TTPI) at the Australian National University (ANU), Australia,The University of Sydney and TTPI at the ANU, Australia
publish_date: Received 19 October 2021, Revised 24 June 2022, Accepted 30 June 2022, Available online 20 July 2022, Version of Record 30 September 2022.
abstract: Exploiting a quasi-natural experiment and using administrative data, we examine the effects of the return-to-work policies’ clawback regime in Disability Insurance (DI) programs on beneficiaries’ ====, allowing them to collect reduced DI payments while working. We compare two return-to-work policies: one with a single rate clawback regime and another featuring a more generous clawback regime, where a reform further increased its generosity. The reform caused an increase in the mean labor supply: beneficiaries who already work, work more, and those who did not work started working. The effects are heterogeneous by beneficiaries’ characteristics, and the increase is driven mainly by top percentiles of earnings. Findings suggest an essential role for the clawback regime in return-to-work policies and targeted policies to increase the labor supply in DI programs.
introduction: Return-to-work policies in Disability Insurance (DI) programs allow beneficiaries to work and collect reduced DI payments under a clawback regime characterized by earnings thresholds, marginal clawback rates, and DI payments. These policies intend to provide financial incentives to beneficiaries to return to the labor force and potentially improve their economic well-being, ensure their broader integration into society, and decrease costs. Previous studies have examined the effects of return-to-work policies on beneficiaries’ labor supply decisions from the introduction of return-to-work policies, changes in the DI payments, eligibility, and screening process. The findings from those studies are mixed.==== There is incipient work on explaining these mixed findings by considering adjustment costs in beneficiaries’ labor supply decisions (Zaresani, 2020). The increase in work incentives induced by a policy change must be large enough to offset the adjustment cost if the goal is to increase the labor supply of the DI beneficiaries. The evidence on the effects of clawback regimes that influence the size of the induced financial incentives, probably due to the lack of such policy variations, is scarce, and it could be another explanation for the mixed findings. Results in this area would be important for understanding labor supply policies’ ramifications and better design of DI policies.====We examine the effects of return-to-work policies’ clawback regimes on DI beneficiaries’ labor supply decisions. Specifically, we compare return-to-work policies in two Canadian provincial DI programs with similar screening, eligibility criteria, and benefits but different clawback regimes. One is Alberta’s “Assured Income for the Severely Handicapped” (hereafter AISH) program, with a generous clawback regime featuring an earnings exemption threshold,==== wherein monthly DI payments gradually get reduced as earnings increase. A reform in April 2012 further increased its generosity, allowing the beneficiaries to work more while collecting a larger portion of their DI payments. The second program is the “Ontario Disability Support Program” (hereafter ODSP), with a single rate clawback regime. We estimate the causal effects of AISH’s clawback regime change on beneficiaries’ earnings and labor force participation decisions in a Difference-in-Differences (DD) framework using ODSP as a control group.==== We also provide suggestive evidence on the relative magnitude of the substitution versus income effects of the reform. To gain further insight into the effects of the reform apart from average effects, we employ a quantile DD framework. Finally, we estimate the elasticity of earnings in the exempted range with respect to a generosity measure of the clawback regime.====We use individual-level longitudinal administrative data on monthly earnings of AISH and ODSP beneficiaries spanning one year and a half of pre- and two years of post-reform obtained from the Alberta and Ontario governments. Observing monthly earnings is essential since the earnings thresholds are monthly based. The data also has information on beneficiaries’ characteristics, including gender, age, family structure, type of disability, and location of residence.====Our analysis provides three main conclusions. First, a more generous clawback regime causes an increase in the mean labor supply along with both the intensive and the extensive margins. The DD model’s estimated effects, controlling for individual fixed effects, are an 11.91% increase in the average inflation-adjusted monthly earnings and a modest 0.78% point increase in the labor force participation rate.====Second, the estimates are heterogeneous by beneficiaries’ family structure, age, gender, type of disability, and location of residence. The estimates are larger for men, younger beneficiaries, those with dependents, those with psychotic disabilities, and beneficiaries who reside in metropolitan areas. Suggestive evidence shows that the income effects of the reform are negligible and that a more generous clawback regime affects work incentives. The quantile DD estimates show that the higher percentiles of the earnings are the drivers of the increase in mean earnings. Findings suggest that targeted policies may work better to encourage DI beneficiaries to return to work.====Third, an increase in the generosity of a clawback regime decreases the portion of the beneficiaries with earnings in the exempted range. The estimated elasticities suggest that a 10% increase in generosity decreases the portion of beneficiaries with earnings in the exempted range by 11.4% and 3.3% for the beneficiaries without and with dependents, respectively.====Our findings provide evidence on the labor supply responses to different clawback regimes of return-to-work policies in DI programs, an important policy domain. While return-to-work policies aim at getting DI beneficiaries into the labor force, empirical findings on the effectiveness of such policies are not conclusive. Hoynes and Moffitt (1999), Benitez-Silva et al. (2011), Weathers II and Hemmeter (2011) and Bütler et al. (2015) find no effects from financial incentives to work in the United States and Switzerland. Meanwhile Zaresani (2018), Campolieti and Riddell (2012), Kostol and Mogstad (2014) and Ruh and Staubli (2019) find positive responses respectively in Canada, Norway and Austria. Beyond a change in financial incentives, medical reassessment of DI recipients and trial work periods in the United States do not appear to affect the labor supply (Autor and Duggan, 2006). Moore (2015) finds positive effects on the labor supply of those who lost their benefits after the removal of drug and alcohol addictions as qualifying conditions for DI programs in the United States. Borghans et al. (2014) and Staubli Staubli (2011) examine the effects of terminating benefits and stricter eligibility criteria in DI programs in the Netherlands and Austria, respectively. They find that individuals substitute DI benefits by collecting more from other social assistance programs. Campolieti (2004); Fortin et al. (2004); Gelber et al. (2017); Lemieux and Milligan (2008) and Gruber (2000) find that providing more generous benefits has negative effects on labor supply in social assistance programs in Canada and the United States. We contribute to this literature by examining the impacts of financial incentives induced by the return-to-work policies’ clawback regime on labor supply decisions.
Title: Return-to-work policies’ clawback regime and labor supply in disability insurance programs

name: Afridi Farzana,Mahajan Kanika,Sangwan Nikita
institution: Indian Statistical Institute (Delhi), National University of Singapore and IZA,Ashoka University, India,Indian Statistical Institute (Delhi), India
publish_date: Received 20 January 2022, Revised 12 July 2022, Accepted 12 July 2022, Available online 16 July 2022, Version of Record 23 July 2022.
abstract: Climate change has increased rainfall uncertainty, leading to greater production risks in agriculture. We examine the gender-differentiated labor impacts of droughts using unique individual-level panel data for agricultural households in India over half a decade. Accounting for unobserved heterogeneity across individuals, we find that women’s workdays are 19% lower than men’s when a drought occurs, driven by the former’s lack of diversification to the non-farm sector. Women are less likely to work outside their village and migrate relative to men in response to droughts and are consequently unable to cope fully with the adverse agricultural productivity shock. We find suggestive evidence in support of social costs emanating from gender norms that constrain women’s access to non-farm work opportunities. The results highlight the gendered impact of climate shocks, potentially exacerbating extant gender gaps in the labor market.
introduction: Climate change has not only resulted in a rise in average temperatures, but it has also increased the incidence and severity of extreme weather events such as droughts and floods (Schiermeier, 2018). Such weather shocks are predicted to rise further if climate change continues unabated (Hsiang, Kopp, 2018, IPCC, 2021). Amongst all economic sectors, agriculture is likely to face the greatest brunt of increasing rainfall uncertainty since more than 75% of the world’s cropped area is rain-fed. Weather shocks resulting from extreme rainfall are, thus, likely to make agricultural incomes and employment prone to productivity risks - a greater concern in developing countries where agricultural systems are largely rain-fed and are also managed by some of the poorest communities. The absence of social insurance and incomplete credit markets in low-income economies underlies the importance of labor as a resource for individuals to cope with such shocks. Additionally, negative short-term productivity shocks such as droughts can potentially exacerbate extant gender differences in labor market outcomes when women’s access to off-farm work opportunities is constrained by social factors such as low mobility.====India, with 40% of its workforce employed in the agriculture sector, has experienced an increased incidence, duration and intensity of droughts, over the last century (Fig. 1).==== In this paper, we combine high frequency, individual-level panel data capturing monthly labor supply and seasonal migration during 2010–14 across eight agro-climatic zones of India to analyze the role of labor markets in mitigating the impact of adverse agricultural production shocks due to droughts. Specifically, we examine the short-term impact of deficient rainfall on individuals’ overall labor force participation, employment on the farm and diversification towards the non-farm sector on both the extensive and intensive margins in rural areas. In a context where men are often better placed to take advantage of available coping mechanisms through their access to other work via seasonal migration, we assess these labor responses by gender. Thus, we also uncover the mechanisms underlying the gender-differentiated impacts on employment.====Our results indicate a fall in women’s labor force participation relative to that of men’s in the event of a drought. We find that women are 7.1% less likely to be employed but 80% more likely to seek work than men in a drought year. On the intensive margin, women’s employment relative to that of men’s is lower by 19%. This is because men increase their days spent on non-farm work by 22.5%, but there is no significant impact on women’s engagement in the non-farm sector. Consequently, women’s non-farm workdays relative to men’s fall by 20.1% in drought years. At the same time, women spend 29.4% more days seeking work, relative to men, when faced with a drought shock. Hence, while men diversify to non-farm sector jobs to cope with droughts, women continue to stay in the farm sector, even as they seek work and their real farm wage earnings (conditional on being employed on the farm) and real daily wage rates fall by 38.1% and 11.4%, respectively.====We find that the lack of substitution towards the non-farm sector in response to a drought by women is due to their restricted mobility. Women are less likely than men to work outside the village or migrate, on average, and more so in drought years. The probability that men take up work outside the village and migrate during a drought increases by 1.7 percentage points (pp) and 0.8 pp, respectively, but there is no impact on women’s workplace location. Men’s higher mobility translates into 18.6% higher non-farm earnings for them relative to women, in the event of a drought.====We find suggestive evidence for social costs emanating from rigid gender norms that place a higher burden of home production and care work on women, as well as concerns around women’s sexual ‘purity’ that inhibit their access to alternative sources of employment beyond their immediate vicinity, as possible explanations behind their lower mobility. Not surprisingly, our analysis shows that women who are younger, married and with young children are not only less likely to divert their labor to the non-farm sector, but are also less likely to migrate relative to men with the same characteristics. These findings are robust to individuals’ unobserved heterogeneity, seasonality, secular and village specific trends. They are also held up by nationally representative district-level panel data.====It is well acknowledged that reliance on insurance is mostly absent, while credit markets are incomplete, in agricultural economies (Morduch, 1995). Hence, utilization of labor, specifically a diversification to the non-farm sector, has been documented as a coping strategy adopted by agricultural households during economic shocks that adversely affect crop yields and incomes (Blakeslee, Fishman, Srinivasan, 2020, Branco, Feres, 2021, Colmer, 2021, Grabrucker, Grimm, 2021, Minale, 2018, Rose, 2001).====Studies also document a fall in real daily farm wages due to a reduction in demand for labor during a drought, with a larger wage reduction in areas with lower access to non-farm opportunities (Auffhammer, Ramanathan, Vincent, 2012, Jayachandran, 2006, Mahajan, 2017, Mueller, Osgood, 2009). Naturally, households often migrate when incomes and livelihoods are adversely affected due to weather shocks like deficient rainfall (see Badiani, Safir, 2008, Marchiori, Maystadt, Schumacher, 2012, Morten, 2019, among many others), heat stress (Cai et al., 2016), floods (Giannelli and Canessa, 2022) and storms (Gröger and Zylberberg, 2016).====However, much less is known about the individual, specifically gender-differentiated responses to these shocks. In the context of developing countries where women are generally less mobile and less likely to search widely for work (Andrabi, Das, Khwaja, 2013, Heath, Mobarak, 2015), men may be better placed to cope with productivity shocks in agriculture and diversify into sectors less subject to weather shocks. But evidence of gender differences in labor response for smoothing the risk emanating from weather shocks, is almost absent, with a few exceptions. Huang et al. (2020) use retrospective employment data for three years from rural China to examine labor re-allocation, in response to temperature and precipitation change, from farm to non-farm activities by gender at the province level. They find no differential impact in take up of non-farm work by gender due to such shocks. In Uganda, where men and women cultivate separate plots of land, Agamile et al. (2021) show that women diversify to more risky, commercial crops and away from subsistence farming while men allocate more time to off-farm labor employment during a drought. However, none of these papers addresses either individual or household level unobserved heterogeneity in assessing the response to climate shocks or explore the underlying mechanisms.====While the existing literature largely focuses on how households diversify their income sources when farm productivity shrinks, we focus on the gender differences in individual decisions when struck by an adverse agricultural productivity shock. Second, and relatedly, unlike the aggregate geographical data used in most previous studies, we underline the potential gender-differentiated impact of climatic shocks such as droughts utilizing novel individual-level panel data over eight agro-climatic zones, collected at a monthly frequency. We are thus able to account for seasonal impacts that are relevant to the agricultural sector.====Furthermore, none of the existing studies provide mechanisms behind the observed gender-differentiated impacts. Our analysis uncovers the underlying mechanisms that can explain the lower likelihood of women substituting towards less risky, non-farm sector jobs, relative to men through detailed data on the nature of employment, place of work, and migration. Unlike most household surveys that capture employment details of only current members of the household and miss out on those members who are temporary migrants, our data allow us to investigate coping mechanisms from farm income losses through engagement in seasonal migration, and the extent to which men and women are able to access non-farm sources of employment through this channel. Our research, thus, also speaks to the literature on migration, by highlighting the role of seasonal migration as a coping mechanism and its potential in exacerbating the impact of weather shocks on gender equality (Cattaneo et al., 2019).====Lastly, through our heterogeneity analyses of the individual-level data which exploits the age, marital status, and parenthood of an individual, we are able to show that social norms around the gendered nature of household production and women’s purity place a cost on women’s access to employment opportunities outside their village.====Indeed, we find suggestive evidence that public employment programs that provide work close to women’s homes, not only mitigate production risks in agriculture in the short-run but also stem gender disparities in employment opportunities. Social norms, thus, can plausibly explain the observed gender-differentiated impacts of droughts in our context. This mechanism, to the best of our knowledge, has not been previously highlighted in the literature. While we do not find evidence in support of gender skill differentials or safety concerns, we are unable to test for gender-differentiated changes in demand for labor in the farm and non-farm sectors, due to data constraints.====The above findings are in contrast to the theoretical prediction and empirical evidence which shows that women’s employment rate increases in response to negative household level idiosyncratic income shocks in low-income economies (Attanasio, Low, Sánchez-Marcos, 2005, Sabarwal, Sinha, Buvinic, 2011, Skoufias, Parker, 2006). Our findings show that while women are more likely to seek work due to negative aggregate income shocks, their employment may not increase if their labor mobility is limited. Additionally, climatic shocks may have long-term effects. Our cross-sectional estimates indicate that gender gaps in non-farm employment and migration are larger in villages facing higher risks from rainfall variability, suggesting that men may permanently shift their occupational structure to the less risky non-farm sector. Indeed, Albert et al. (2021) finds that regions facing increased frequency of droughts witness a shift in employment towards the non-farm sector and an increase in population outflows over two decades in Brazil. In contrast, Liu et al. (2021) and Jessoe et al. (2018) show that long-term temperature increases reduce non-farm employment share and lower rural-urban migration rates in India and Mexico, respectively. Our findings, thus, call for further research on the longer-term effects of weather shocks, from a gender perspective.====The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. In the next section, we set up the conceptual framework. Section 3 describes the data used in the analysis and discusses the estimation strategy. The results and their robustness are presented in Section 4. We discuss the mechanisms that underlie our findings in Section 5, and conclude in Section 6.
Title: The gendered effects of droughts: Production shocks and labor response in agriculture

name: Caliendo Marco,Wittbrodt Linda
institution: University of Potsdam, Center for Economic Policy Analysis (CEPA), Germany,IZA, BSE, DIW, IAB, Germany
publish_date: Received 8 December 2021, Revised 12 July 2022, Accepted 13 July 2022, Available online 16 July 2022, Version of Record 23 August 2022.
abstract: In many countries, women are over-represented among low-wage employees, which is why a wage floor could benefit them particularly. Following this notion, we analyse the impact of the German minimum wage introduction in 2015 on the gender wage gap. Germany poses an interesting case study in this context, since it has a rather high gender wage gap and set the minimum wage at a relatively high level, affecting more than four million employees. Based on individual data from the Structure of Earnings Survey, containing information for over one million employees working in 60,000 firms, we use a difference-in-difference framework that exploits regional differences in the bite of the minimum wage. We find a significant negative effect of the minimum wage on the regional gender wage gap. Between 2014 and 2018, the gap at the 10th percentile of the wage distribution was reduced by 4.6 percentage points (or 32%) in regions that were strongly affected by the minimum wage compared to less affected regions. For the gap at the 25th percentile, the effect still amounted to ====18%, while for the mean it was smaller (====11%) and not particularly robust. We thus find that the minimum wage can indeed reduce gender wage disparities. While the effect is highest for the low-paid, it also reaches up into higher parts of the wage distribution.
introduction: The differences between men’s and women’s earnings have been studied extensively over recent years. One of its dimensions is the fact that women are often overrepresented among the low-paid employees (Card, Cardoso, Kline, 2016, Kahn, 2015). This leads to the existence of a wage gap at the bottom of the distribution, also called ‘sticky floors’, and one possible way to alleviate this issue is the introduction of a minimum wage. If female employees are more prevalent among the wage floor beneficiaries than their male counterparts, they should also be disproportionately affected by a minimum wage, which would reduce wage disparities and thus the gender wage gap. In their seminal paper, DiNardo et al. (1996) find that labour market institutions such as a minimum wage can indeed reduce inequality, especially so for women. This line of research has been continued by an ample number of studies establishing a negative relationship between the minimum wage and the gender wage gap for a variety of countries.====In this context, Germany poses an interesting case study. On the one hand, it is a country with a relatively high gender wage gap, especially at the bottom of the wage distribution. In 2014, the difference between the earnings of full-time employed men and full-time employed women amounted to 17.2 percent in Germany, placing it in the upper third of countries with the highest gaps, above the OECD average (see Fig. 1a).==== At the first decile of the wage distribution, Germany even shows a wage difference of 18.2% in 2014, placing it among the eight countries with the highest gaps among low-income earners, and well above the United States and the United Kingdom (see Fig. 1b). It is thus evident that Germany suffers from high gender wage discrepancies in an OECD comparison, especially among low-wage earners.==== On the other hand, Germany introduced a nationwide minimum wage in 2015, which was set at a comparably high level and had only few exemptions.==== With € 8.50 gross per hour, it ranked among the highest wage floors in Europe in terms of purchasing power (Caliendo et al., 2019). Its level is to be re-evaluated every two years, and it was increased to € 8.84 in January 2017, being followed by additional increases in 2019 and the subsequent years (Mindestlohnkommission, Mindestlohnkommission, Mindestlohnkommission). Caused by its high initial value, the reform affected about four million employees, i.e. about ten percent of the eligible workers (Destatis, 2016). Among them, women were vastly overrepresented, since they accounted for two-thirds of affected employees (Burauel, Caliendo, Fedorets, Grabka, Schröder, Schupp, Wittbrodt, 2017, Mindestlohnkommission). This has been attributed to insufficient regulations of the low-pay sector and gender segregation, which lead to an unequal coverage of collective bargaining agreements for men and women (Grimshaw, Rubery, 2013, Herzog-Stein, Lübker, Pusch, Schulten, Watt, 2018). Accordingly, the introduction of the wage floor could have an influence on gender inequality. In a simulation study, Boll et al. (2015) predict that in the absence of job losses, the minimum wage could reduce the average gender wage gap in Germany by 2.5 percentage points; and with job losses, the effect could even be larger. This points to a potential caveat, namely that low-paid women quitting or losing their jobs could cause a decrease in the gap. However, since all ex-post evaluation studies find only small employment effects and no strong evidence of gender-specific job-losses (see, e.g., Bonin, Isphording, Krause, Lichter, Pestel, Rinne, Caliendo, Obst, Preuss, Schröder, Grabka, Caliendo, Schröder, Wittbrodt, 2019, Pestel, Bonin, Isphording, Gregory, Caliendo), this does not seem to be an issue in Germany.====In our analysis, we mainly employ data from 2014 and 2018, which we obtain from the Structure of Earnings Survey (SES), a large obligatory survey that comprises detailed wage information for over one million employees working in 60,000 firms. First, we descriptively look at the wages of male and female employees who are eligible for the minimum wage and compare the wage gap in 2014 with the one in 2018. Second, following Card (1992), we make use of regional variation in the “minimum wage bite”, i.e. the degree to which a region is affected by the minimum wage, and analyse the causal effects of the minimum wage introduction on regional gender wage gaps.==== We are able to identify a significant effect on the wage gap at the regional level, especially for low-paid employees. Between 2014 and 2018, the gap at the 10th percentile was reduced by 4.6 percentage points (or 32%) in regions that were strongly affected by the minimum wage compared to less affected regions. For the gap at the 25th percentile, the effect still amounted to ====18%, while for the mean it was smaller (====11%) and not particularly robust. Using a continuous bite measure, we can show that an increase in a region’s bite by ten percentage points, reduces the wage at the 10th percentile by 3.3 percentage points. This thus shows that the minimum wage reform led to a significant decrease in the wage gap especially at the bottom of the wage distribution.====The remainder of this paper proceeds as follows. Section 2 reviews the previous literature on gender-specific minimum wage effects on wages and presents the data that we use. Additionally, it offers a first descriptive overview of the gender-specific wages before and after the reform, as well as the regional differences in the wage gap and the bite measure. Section 3.2 then presents the identification strategy and displays the results of the main estimation and the robustness analyses. In Section 4, we summarise our results.
Title: Did the minimum wage reduce the gender wage gap in Germany?

name: Modena Francesca,Rettore Enrico,Tanzi Giulia Martina
institution: Bank of Italy, Trento Branch, Economic Research Unit, Italy,Department of Economics and Management, University of Padova and FBK-IRVAPP, Italy,Bank of Italy, Milano Branch, Economic Research Unit, Italy
publish_date: Received 21 October 2021, Revised 4 July 2022, Accepted 6 July 2022, Available online 8 July 2022, Version of Record 14 July 2022.
abstract: This paper exploits student-level administrative data on the population of Italian university students from 2006 to 2014, in order to analyse the effects of high-performing (HP) male and female peers on individual ====, according to the gender of the student. The identification strategy is based on quasi-random variations in the exposure to HP peers across cohorts, within the same university and the same degree programme. The impact of the gender of HP students, proxied by their high school final grade, is asymmetric. We found that the beneficial effects of HP peers are stronger on same-gender students and, in particular, for females. Moreover, while female HP students also positively influence male students, HP males do not generally exert any impact on their female peers. The exposure to male HP students becomes negative for low-ability students.
introduction: An overwhelming number of studies have tried to estimate the extent to which peer ability can influence students individual achievement. Most papers have observed the positive effects of high-ability peers, but some works have highlighted the potentially negative effect of competition and pressure on certain types of students (Feld, Zölitz, 2017, Fischer, 2017). In fact, from a theoretical point of view, the exposure to high-performing peers could be performance-enhancing, through knowledge spillovers or motivation, or it may have the reverse effect of reducing incentives to make an effort, due to the negative impact on self-perception. The effects of exposure to high-ability peers may vary according to the gender of the students and to the gender of the peer. In fact, a rich and growing line of research has provided evidence that women and men are likely to differ with respect to psychological attitudes, self-esteem, risk preferences, and attitudes toward competition and collaboration (Azmat, Petrongolo, 2014, Croson, Gneezy, 2009, Eyal, Epley, 2017, Marianne, 2011). This may have important implications for peer interactions and for the ways in which the high-ability peers can influence students’ behaviour and performance.====Given these psychological and behavioural differences across genders, a very recent strand of the peer effects literature has started to study the interplay between peer ability and gender (Cools, Fernández, Patacchini, Feld, Zölitz, 2022, Mouganie, Wang, 2020, Pagani, Pica, 2021). At the moment, there is only a handful of studies that combine the effects of ability and gender and, furthermore, it is hard to obtain a unified pattern for the findings, since the evidence originates from different educational levels and from more or less selected samples of students’ populations.====In line with this literature, this paper estimates the impacts of high-performing (HP) peers on individual performance in tertiary education, differentiating by the gender of the student and by the gender of the HP peers. Two reasons make the study of peer effects at the university level particularly interesting. First, the research into the higher education setting is very limited despite the peculiarity of the interactions between males and females at this level of education, as compared to lower levels (Sacerdote, 2011). During the tertiary education students are already young adults that have self-selected fully into their educational trajectories, according to their preferences, specific skills, gender norms, past schooling experience and relative achievements. Thus, finding that peer effects are determinant even at this stage would strengthen the case for the importance of peer effects and the social context in a broader sense. Second, previous papers on higher education had access to data from a single university or field of study but it is plausible that peer dynamics strongly differ depending on the context (for example, the field of study, the gender composition, the attractiveness of the university.). Differently, this paper exploits rich administrative data covering the universe of Italian university students for several years.====In this work we ask the following questions: does exposure to more HP females or males positively affect a student’s performance? Are female or male HP peers more effective in influencing the other students? Do these effects differ according to whether the student has the same or a different gender from his/her HP peers? We address these questions using student-level administrative data that cover the population of the Italian university students from 2006 to 2014 (Anagrafe Nazionale Studenti). The data follow students from enrolment to graduation/dropout and provide a lot of information on the academic career of the student and of his/her peers and on their educational background. We estimate the effects of the HP peers that are enrolled, in the first year, in the same degree programme and university on several individual outcomes. We focus on the effects on first-year academic academic performance (number of credits achieved, the average grade obtained in the exams and the probability of dropping out), as well as on the students’ final academic outcome (probability of graduating and final grades).====There are two methodological problems that are important to take into account in the identification strategy: the selection and the reflection problems. To solve the selection problem, we identify the causal effect by exploiting variations in the exposure of students to HP peers across cohorts within university and degree programme. The basic idea is to compare the outcomes of students from adjacent cohorts that are enrolled in the same university/degree, exposed to different fractions of HP female and male students (with respect to the total number of peers) due to purely random factors. This strategy, introduced by Hoxby (2000), is based on the assumption that a student may make decisions based on the overall characteristics of the degree programme/university, but that s/he does not decide to enroll on the basis of the specific characteristics of their cohort (in terms of ability and gender) within the same degree programme and university. Thus, the variation due to differences across cohorts within the same degree program and university can be treated as quasi-random.====The second methodological problem is reflection. As defined in (Manski, 1993), it is impossible to distinguish the effect of peers on the individual from the effect of the individual on peers because they are simultaneously determined. To solve this problem, we define the HP students according to the final grade they obtained in high school, before the enrollment in a university program.====Consistently with earlier studies, we find that, after controlling for student’s ability and other characteristics, the fraction of HP students is relevant for students achievement. In addition we find a clear asymmetry in the peer effect depending on student and peers genders. In particular, we found that same-gender HP peers have the strongest positive effects. This can be rationalized within the framework of the role models that, applied in the education context, emphasized psychological mechanisms that act on students’ efforts and motivation in order to explain individual outcomes==== Being surrounded by students who are ’similar’ in terms of gender and observing them doing particularly well may positively affect their perception of themselves, their study efforts, attitudes towards class and socializing behaviour, since they may feel more confident of being in the appropriate setting. The stronger positive effect found when the HP peerstudent gender is matched may be also the result of enhanced peer interaction between peers of the same sex, because similarity allows students to help each other more easily and spend time together.====The second important result of this analysis refers to the different effect of HP males and females on the opposite-gender students. In fact, on the one hand, we find that HP females have beneficial effects on males too (even if smaller in magnitude). This can be explained by the fact that women appear to be more collaborative than men (Guarin, Babin, 2021, Molina, Gimenez-Nadal, Cuesta, Garcia-Lazaro, Moreno, Sanchez, 2013), regardless of the gender of the other person. On the other hand, HP males do not exert any effect on their female peers and when they do so - for example when considering the probability of getting higher grades - this effect can even become negative. This is consistent with the psychological theories and with the results of the literature according to which women tend to be discouraged by competition with men (Bordalo, Coffman, Gennaioli, Shleifer, 2019, Niederle, Segal, Vesterlund, 2013).====We complete our analysis by showing that the positive impact of the exposure to female HP peers is not only stronger in the short run: in fact, female HP peers also affect students’ long-term educational attainment (in terms of the probability of completing college education and the final grade obtained), with positive effects on human capital accumulation and on the efficiency of the universities. As regards the magnitude of the estimated effects, overall we show that HP peer mildly affect students academic outcomes, but the impact varies substantially according to the considered academic outcome.====Finally, we observe some heterogeneous effects according to student’s and degree’ characteristics. First, adverse effects from HP male peers are found when we consider low ability students but, in this case, this result is independent of gender. Second, all the peer effects are weaker if the class is heterogeneous in terms of ability. Third, some positive effects coming from HP males emerge when we consider high-ability female students, such as those enrolled in STEM fields.====As mentioned, the novelty of our paper refers to the fact that we are among the firsts to look simultaneously at the effects of gender and ability and there is certainly room for research for better understanding the relationship between these two factors. Our main references are Pagani and Pica (2021), who focus on primary schools, Busso et al. (2021), who analyse interactions in middle schools, while Mouganie and Wang (2020) and Cools et al. (2021) assess peer effects in high schools.
